From the ML discussion, we haven't got any consensus. Dropping python35 job does not make sense at the moment. Adding py37 job in Stein might makes sense but we don't drop python3.5 support in Stein.

What does "Stein+" mean precisely? Does it include Stein? It is not clear.

I put -2 until we get the community consensus.'}, {'account_id': 17499, 'date': '2018-11-19 15:39:18.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Workflow-1 by Filippo Inzaghi <zhao.daqing@99cloud.net>

Add extra volume types to AIO

This change adds example volume types in AIO. It will allow tests to
enter code paths that create volume types and associate QoS specs.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/617051
Change-Id: I0cb77b1958e586e35458368ec00f4f167d031923
(cherry picked from commit 80c7c23a68229b97080a784b6164ea78d79192d4)

Add skip_checks classmethod

The conditions skip snippet should reside on skip_checks
method rather than resource_setup method.

subject: Check NotFound with pool property in pool member
messages:
[{'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-02-07 06:18:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25395, 'date': '2018-02-07 08:09:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26297, 'date': '2018-02-07 13:42:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27552, 'date': '2018-02-07 13:48:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-02-07 16:49:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I don't think this bug is unique to Octavia. Since I953a52e9b165d3ea4fb2fc57ceea8083c7f8f30c we try to translate properties *after* loading their stored values from the database while deleting a resource: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/heat/tree/heat/engine/resource.py#n1995

This is bad, we should never do anything that relies on live data during a delete (for exactly this reason). I think we should fix that (by storing the translated properties in the DB, if they aren't already).

I also don't think this is a valid fix - IIUC it's not the resource that we're deleting itself that is not found, but one that is referenced in one of its properties. At least in the general case that isn't something we want to ignore, because it can result in the resource itself getting left behind when Heat thinks it's deleted."}, {'account_id': 25395, 'date': '2018-02-08 06:10:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

> I don't think this bug is unique to Octavia. Since
 > I953a52e9b165d3ea4fb2fc57ceea8083c7f8f30c we try to translate
 > properties *after* loading their stored values from the database
 > while deleting a resource: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/heat/tree/heat/engine/resource.py#n1995
 > 
 > This is bad, we should never do anything that relies on live data
 > during a delete (for exactly this reason). I think we should fix
 > that (by storing the translated properties in the DB, if they
 > aren't already).
 > 
 > I also don't think this is a valid fix - IIUC it's not the resource
 > that we're deleting itself that is not found, but one that is
 > referenced in one of its properties. At least in the general case
 > that isn't something we want to ignore, because it can result in
 > the resource itself getting left behind when Heat thinks it's
 > deleted.

I agree."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-02-09 02:02:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

On reflection, there doesn't appear to be a simple way to fix this globally.

Also, this fix is valid, because the PoolMember is effectively a subresource of the Pool, so deletion of the pool does imply deletion of the member and there is nothing else to clean up.

Since I don't have any better ideas, I'm changing my vote to +2."}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2018-02-09 05:06:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-05-09 11:23:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-05-09 11:23:48.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bug/1747836 to Story: #1747836'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-05-09 11:23:59.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from Story: #1747836 to story/1747836'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-05-09 12:49:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-05-10 17:20:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-06-27 14:06:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

Unit test would be nice.'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2018-06-27 14:43:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

The same issue exists for L7Rule resource. But a separate patch would be fine too.

+1 on adding unit tests.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-06-27 17:47:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-06-27 17:51:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-06-28 03:17:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-06-28 05:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

My test was incorrect I think.get_pool side_effect was by mistake a list with one NotFound.

should be:

self.member.client_plugin().get_pool.side_effect = exceptions.NotFound(404)


I think it would possibly work as we ignore NotFound error in _check_deleted()[1]

We call property as input for some octavia resources. It will wrap
not found message in ValueError exception, which means we can't
find it when checking for NotFound exception.
Add check when checking not found during delete.
Closes-Bug: #1747836

Change-Id: Ibc8f5d125436f0f8c9ea5a62d5be4e4f8b3c4401

checking not found during delete, when getting ValueError during
translating pool.

Task: #16037

commit_message:
Check NotFound with pool property in pool member

We use pool property directly when create/update/delete/show pool member.
Which will try to translate and raise value error when it's actually pool
not found. In cases like pool can not be found, we will raise NotFound
exception instead a value error.

Story: #1747836
Task: #16037

Change-Id: Ibc8f5d125436f0f8c9ea5a62d5be4e4f8b3c4401

If we use tests to ensure default policies don't change, it becomes
easier to evolve policies using TDD. This commit adds a test that does
something different with context object to model a token that matches
the policy we changed in the previous patchset.

Modeling tokens using context objects should give us the flexibility

commit_message:
DO NOT MERGE: Add an example test for policy change

If we use tests to ensure default policies don't change, it becomes
easier to evolve policies using TDD. This commit adds a test that does
something different with context object to model a token that matches
the policy we changed in the previous patchset.

Modeling tokens using context objects should give us the flexibility
express tokens from keystone to test cinder's API without having to
deal with an actual integration test.

Change-Id: I823af05deee823d0a47ad39016c85fc3da5cedd4

[{'created': '2018-09-20 14:56:56.000000000', 'message': "DO NOT MERGE: Showcase policy protection with tests

This is an example to show that unit tests should fail when
changing default policy values.

By testing the default policies when accessing the API, we can ensure
changes like this don't slip through the gate due to a mocked
policy enforcement or policy overridden in the tests.

This patch won't pass check because
cinder.tests.unit.api.v3.test_volume_protection.VolumeProtectionTests
failed, which is explicitly meant to test policy coverage with
cinder's API.

Change-Id: I1ded7ecffed5ceb7cd718b0becbf8e9b8a9c0457
"}]
commit_message:
DO NOT MERGE: Showcase policy protection with tests

This is an example to show that unit tests should fail when
changing default policy values.

By testing the default policies when accessing the API, we can ensure
changes like this don't slip through the gate due to a mocked
policy enforcement or policy overridden in the tests.

This patch won't pass check because
cinder.tests.unit.api.v3.test_volume_protection.VolumeProtectionTests
failed, which is explicitly meant to test policy coverage with
cinder's API.

Change-Id: I1ded7ecffed5ceb7cd718b0becbf8e9b8a9c0457

[{'created': '2018-09-12 19:26:18.000000000', 'message': 'NetApp ONTAP: Fix use of multiple subnets with DHSS=True

NetApp ONTAP Multi-SVM driver was raising an error while trying to
create shares on multiple subnets that belong to the same neutron
network, as it was trying to map multiple ipspaces to the same VLAN
port.

This fix allows the driver to use the same ipspace and VLAN port across
all subnets belonging to the same neutron network.

Change-Id: If9cbb34a890ee44806c404085e40cc924a1296a7
Closes-Bug: #1774159

commit_message:
NetApp ONTAP: Fix use of multiple subnets with DHSS=True

NetApp ONTAP Multi-SVM driver was raising an error while trying to
create shares on multiple subnets that belong to the same neutron
network, as it was trying to map multiple ipspaces to the same VLAN
port.

This fix allows the driver to use the same ipspace and VLAN port across
all subnets belonging to the same neutron network.

Change-Id: If9cbb34a890ee44806c404085e40cc924a1296a7
Closes-Bug: #1774159

[{'created': '2018-09-26 11:17:20.000000000', 'message': 'Fix curly brackets for ntp::servers: to prevent HTML escaping

According to MUSTACHE(5) documentation to prevent HTML escaping
value should be in triple curly brackets {{{ }}}. This change
adds missing brackets around ntp::servers: which resulted
improper values to be in hieradata.

Closes-Bug: #1794501
'}]
commit_message:
Fix curly brackets for ntp::servers: to prevent HTML escaping

According to MUSTACHE(5) documentation to prevent HTML escaping
value should be in triple curly brackets {{{ }}}. This change
adds missing brackets around ntp::servers: which resulted
improper values to be in hieradata.

Change-Id: Ia3f1343704a660a28ba4e48513eb2983849e87c3
Closes-Bug: #1794501

commit_message:
Make $SSH_OPTIONS overrideable

In some cases, it may be desireable to override $SSH_OPTIONS as used by
the deployed-server get-occ-config.sh script. Particularly in
environments that wish to remove -tt.

This patches makes it so that the value can be overridden via the shell.

Change-Id: I14ab6765b3e55f602bb8ae56a313fce9812e3f59
Closes-Bug: #1800834

commit_message:
Set `TraceEnable` directive for apache to 'Off'

Openstack service don't support TRACE requests, so there is little
point allowing TRACE for apache.

Change-Id: I396a4c3bfab8f353d038b011d5dc8029f4137a57
Closes-Bug: #1801298
(cherry picked from commit 2777c2b7d8ebb9144b2b6fea8649dbfae350c46b)

commit_message:
Add dev mode install playbook for source installs

The following playbook will produce a modified image with Python source
code installed via pip. To minimize dependencies within the container
we generate the sdist locally and then copy it into the resulting
container image as an sdist tarball to run pip install locally.

Useful for local ad-hoc testing of upstream patches without
having to build and RPM in those cases.

Change-Id: I93c0e86b2e421b0bcb777d536fcb0d30e0ee3b68

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-29 12:02:23.000000000', 'message': "Set the number of RPC workers to 1 for non SRIOV OVN setups

OVN based backend setups don't need RPC communications as they
don't deploy Neutron agents (except for the SRIOV case).

For this reason and to minimize the resources used, this patch
is setting the number of RPC workers to the minimum, which is 1.

Change-Id: Icf84516f24873717cb7615233d2e6341414abfc7
Closes-Bug: #1786952
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit c677a4ba406f9e8d6ee82e764f9e4b56107624fe)
"}]
commit_message:
Set the number of RPC workers to 1 for non SRIOV OVN setups

OVN based backend setups don't need RPC communications as they
don't deploy Neutron agents (except for the SRIOV case).

For this reason and to minimize the resources used, this patch
is setting the number of RPC workers to the minimum, which is 1.

Change-Id: Icf84516f24873717cb7615233d2e6341414abfc7
Closes-Bug: #1786952
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit c677a4ba406f9e8d6ee82e764f9e4b56107624fe)

commit_message:
Add a document for creating DB revisions

This gives some basic documentation for creating a revision using
alembic. It then links to the alembic tutorial for more information.

Change-Id: I8647aaa55dca537d95c7c03753f2a24f364f0ddf

[{'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2018-11-16 20:59:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-11-19 16:20:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The unit test failure looks valid'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2018-11-19 21:10:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> The unit test failure looks valid

Agreed. 

I identified the patch [0] which provides the missing get_object_service function [1] though there are seven patches in between queens and pike [2][3] so backporting would be non-trivial. Furthermore, the code to be backported wouldn't help the FFU case I am interested in trying to fix here because my understanding is that puppet-ceph is used during pike to queens FFU step. Thus, I think I should abandon this patch.

[{'created': '2018-11-16 20:59:16.000000000', 'message': 'Persist ceph-ansible fetch_directory using mistral

When scaling ceph monitors, ceph-ansible uses context from the
fetch_directory to prevent new monitors from behaving like they
are the only monitors.

Save the fetch_directory in swift after each ceph-ansible playbook
run; and if there is a fetch directory in swift, restore it before
each playbook run.

Note that https://review.openstack.org/#/c/582811 only resolves
1769769 for Master where config-download external deploy tasks
run ceph-ansible. This change resolves 1769769 when using mistral
for Queens/Pike (when backported).

Closes-Bug: #1769769
(cherry picked from commit 2f300dfd906ae747e626efa27f4dc0380aef361a)

Conflicts:
	setup.cfg
	workbooks/ceph-ansible.yaml

Change-Id: I45916f4d3458dd4de1ae0e0cb680a29d2dcb09f6
'}]
commit_message:
Persist ceph-ansible fetch_directory using mistral

When scaling ceph monitors, ceph-ansible uses context from the
fetch_directory to prevent new monitors from behaving like they
are the only monitors.

Save the fetch_directory in swift after each ceph-ansible playbook
run; and if there is a fetch directory in swift, restore it before
each playbook run.

Note that https://review.openstack.org/#/c/582811 only resolves
1769769 for Master where config-download external deploy tasks
run ceph-ansible. This change resolves 1769769 when using mistral
for Queens/Pike (when backported).

Closes-Bug: #1769769
(cherry picked from commit 2f300dfd906ae747e626efa27f4dc0380aef361a)

Conflicts:
	setup.cfg
	workbooks/ceph-ansible.yaml

Change-Id: I45916f4d3458dd4de1ae0e0cb680a29d2dcb09f6

subject: Fix bug in updating inventory file from an existing inventory
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1390, 'name': 'Paul Bourke', 'email': 'pauldbourke@proton.me', 'username': 'pauldbourke'}, {'_account_id': 16520, 'name': 'Borne Mace', 'email': 'borne.mace@oracle.com', 'username': 'bmace'}, {'_account_id': 16704, 'name': 'James McCarthy', 'email': 'james.m.mccarthy@oracle.com', 'username': 'jmccarthy'}, {'_account_id': 17386, 'name': 'Steve Noyes', 'email': 'steve.noyes@oracle.com', 'username': 'ssn1ssn'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23479, 'name': 'Murali Annamneni', 'email': 'murali.annamneni@oracle.com', 'username': 'mannamne'}, {'_account_id': 24147, 'name': 'Mark Giles', 'email': 'mark.giles@oracle.com', 'username': 'mark-giles'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 23479, 'date': '2018-07-20 16:12:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23479, 'date': '2018-07-23 10:19:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 17386, 'date': '2018-07-23 12:49:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16520, 'date': '2018-08-07 23:42:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I tend to agree with Steve on this.  If we find that we want to tweak the supported bit on the service, we can do that, but finding that the service bit was changed, and then replacing the whole service, seems a bit odd / heavy handed to me.  I think the logic should either be changed to be more selective of what is changed, or some documentation should be added in the code to explain the intent.'}, {'account_id': 23479, 'date': '2018-08-23 14:24:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The idea here is to avoid one elif block when both status & group changed or to avoid more elif if multiple things changed. I can add comments.'}, {'account_id': 23479, 'date': '2018-08-23 14:24:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 16520, 'date': '2018-08-24 17:09:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I don't understand your comment about not wanting else if statements.  We already have two here.  The new comments aren't useful imo and are just stating the obvious.  I think the concern that Steve and I both have is that you are checking the state of X and actually changing the state of X, Y and Z and eventually more things if more elements are added to the service object.  If you don't like else ifs here for some reason you can always break this out into some sort of service comparator, but optimally I still think you should only change what needs to be changed, as I think I mentioned in a previous comment this is also going to be very problematic, on the group comparison side, if they end up having custom groups as you will wipe out the association in your group update."}, {'account_id': 23479, 'date': '2018-11-13 16:27:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 23479, 'date': '2018-11-13 16:27:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 16520, 'date': '2018-11-13 20:54:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Those new changes look better.  Once you get it to pass pep8 i'm happy to give it the +2."}, {'account_id': 23479, 'date': '2018-11-14 12:51:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 23479, 'date': '2018-11-14 16:26:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 16520, 'date': '2018-11-14 17:39:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 24147, 'date': '2018-11-14 17:57:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23479, 'date': '2018-11-15 14:31:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 23479, 'date': '2018-11-15 14:35:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 17386, 'date': '2018-11-15 19:03:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17386, 'date': '2018-11-15 19:16:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

(2 comments)

Just a minor comment. The trouble with doing the sort in services is that it is a special case that is unique to groups.I don't think that we sort any of the other inventory lists.

If someone ever changes that sort, you'd never know why it would break upgrade. It would be better to keep the sort together with where you need the sorted list."}, {'account_id': 23479, 'date': '2018-11-15 20:23:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > Just a minor comment. The trouble with doing the sort in services
 > is that it is a special case that is unique to groups.I don't think
 > that we sort any of the other inventory lists.
 > 
 > If someone ever changes that sort, you'd never know why it would
 > break upgrade. It would be better to keep the sort together with
 > where you need the sorted list.

sort() on lists doesn't return anything (i tested with sample code :)). So, l1.sort() != l2.sort() is invalid.
And another reason for sorting is because following 2 lists are not same - 
l1 = ["g1", "g2"] & l2 = ["g2", "g1"];
If we compare these 2 without sorting, they wont match. Hence, I added sort() .
I added sort() eachtime the groupnames list changes (append/remove), so, get_groupnames() always returns sorted list.

And reg. upgrade, sorry I can't think loud here, can you please elaborate how it can fail due to sort? Are these 2 different wrt upgrade ?
[service1]
g1
g2

[service1]
g2
g1'}, {'account_id': 17386, 'date': '2018-11-16 17:55:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> > (2 comments)
 > >
 > > Just a minor comment. The trouble with doing the sort in services
 > > is that it is a special case that is unique to groups.I don't
 > think
 > > that we sort any of the other inventory lists.
 > >
 > > If someone ever changes that sort, you'd never know why it would
 > > break upgrade. It would be better to keep the sort together with
 > > where you need the sorted list.
 > 
 > sort() on lists doesn't return anything (i tested with sample code
 > :)). So, l1.sort() != l2.sort() is invalid.
 > And another reason for sorting is because following 2 lists are not
 > same -
 > l1 = ["g1", "g2"] & l2 = ["g2", "g1"];
 > If we compare these 2 without sorting, they wont match. Hence, I
 > added sort() .
 > I added sort() eachtime the groupnames list changes
 > (append/remove), so, get_groupnames() always returns sorted list.
 > 
 > And reg. upgrade, sorry I can't think loud here, can you please
 > elaborate how it can fail due to sort? Are these 2 different wrt
 > upgrade ?
 > [service1]
 > g1
 > g2
 > 
 > [service1]
 > g2
 > g1

You're right that sort() is not good for this, but sorted(a) == sorted(b) will work ok.

My point about not doing the sort down in services is that it's not obvious why we sort just that and not all the other lists we keep in inventory. It makes it riskier that some future change could change that without understanding why. (And I don't think it would be a good idea to sort those other ones either)'}, {'account_id': 23479, 'date': '2018-11-17 19:56:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 17386, 'date': '2018-11-19 15:17:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 16520, 'date': '2018-11-19 20:49:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Fix bug in updating inventory file from an existing inventory

While updating inventory from an existing to new, if a
service newly enabled or its group changed, its not getting
reflected in new inventory file. So, added checks few checks in
upgrade path.

Change-Id: I276f051c82db9d539ae3b0e156957b6dacfe2968

It's not been pep8 or anything so lovely like that."}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-11-04 01:42:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

well, Nova already doesn't really use the oslo fixtures anyway, e.g. things like https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/tests/fixtures.py#L658 are entirely novel to Nova and I originally had intended for the oslo_db system to replace it, which is partially why the oslo_db system has a lot of moving pieces.  It was to suit what I saw in Nova at the time (but it was pre-placement and even pre-cells, so the issue is much more challenging now in any case), as well as meeting the needs of very different projects like Neutron.     If Opportunistic is not fitting in here, I'd need to find time to take a look at it which I can do if that is critical here.  I thought you were only having problems with that server_default."}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-11-04 01:44:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

though this is "placement", which seems to be separate from Nova, OK, thought that was under the same umbrella...'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-11-04 01:53:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

still typing and looking out loud, that gist doesn't look so terrible, you're still using provision.Backend() which is where all the heavy lifting is.   

part of what makes oslo_db's system quite difficult is that it uses testresources.   Which is a clever system, but I found it very difficult to understand for a long time, and actually if I got into that code again I'd have to re-familiarize with it.   At the time, since what I was getting the opportunistic fixture to do had functional overlap with what testresources was intended to do, it was agreed that I should be integrating it.   That it has made the system a lot more complicated and now people are just passing over it, thereby fully reversing the all the efforts to have a "non-duplicated solution" in play so that everyone is again having to roll their own, is not ideal.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-04 12:24:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Thanks for the responses MIke, I was frustrated yesterday so my moan about Opportunistic probably came across as bit more trashing that I meant. It appears to be ideal for the common case, but placement to the side that a bit (uses [placement_database]/connection for config is the big one). I agree that testresources is challenging and being unable to untangle that was probably the root of my difficulty.

The situation here is that the placement service has been extracted out of the nova repo to its own. As a result it has to start managing its own database migrations and tests so it seemed an ideal time to switch to alembic. We borrowed some tests from Ironic and cargo-culted. Trying to resolve the issue with the existing mixins had me going down many dead ends.

if the gist is good enough, then I reckon just going with it is probably the way to go (modulo fixing the lock file location).

It probably also needs some additional exceptions handled near the skipTest calls.

Ed, your thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-11-05 03:10:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

by all means, get Alembic in there.  That's absolutely critical because nobody is maintaining SQLAlchemy-Migrate at all.   Use the gist for now which seems to look 95% like oslo's fixture in any case.   when it's all working we can try someday (or not) to swap in the full oslo.db fixture."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-05 13:11:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-05 13:48:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Workflow-1

This is still closer but one problem remains.

This failure http://logs.openstack.org/39/614539/9/check/openstack-tox-functional-py36/d497677/testr_results.html.gz shows that configuration of a postgresql or mysql engine can leak over into the other tests if the tests and process line up just so.

The fix might be as straightforward as reseting the global at https://github.com/openstack/placement/blob/master/placement/tests/fixtures.py#L30 allowing configure to be called again, but because of the harden placement config, we'll also need to reset the run_once decorator.

I guess I'll try that.

Any other ideas?"}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-11-05 14:26:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

I haven't looked at test runner stuff in general in well over a year.   But IIRC, the usual test architecture is that tests are running in individual processes, and no threads are being used.   The error you show looks like previous test artifacts not being cleaned up.   There needs to be a hard/clear cleanup that works in one of three ways:  the first is that the previous test took place in a transaction that is then fully rolled back.  this is not really appropriate for openstack, not the least of which because MySQL doesn't have transactional DDL so cannot apply to migration tests but also it's a little bit hard to get right.   The next is that DELETE statements are run against all the tables in the schema and then whatever fixture rows need to exist are re-INSERTed.  This is also difficult to get right, and again doesn't apply to migration tests.   The third is the safest and easiest way but has the disadvantage of being slow, which is you drop the whole schema and re-create it all over again on each test.   The two intricacies here are that the schema can either be re-created by running a create_all() over the existing model (fast, works on SQLite), or by running through all the migrations (slow, often doesn't work on SQLite).   Nova has invented an additional system of recreating the schema which is specific to SQLite here: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/tests/fixtures.py#L658

The large number of fixtures you see in oslo_db correspond to all of these different techniques.    The drop and recreate the whole schema approach is likely the most common.   Most services run all their tests on SQLite only, and then only migration tests are run on Postgresql/MySQL using the opportunistic mixin.

I haven't looked at any code as yet because I need to find a large block of time to dedicate to a full run-through of this suite, but you want to start out with tests running only on SQLite except for migration tests, and you want to make sure everything is blown away both database-wise and global-variable-wise at the end of each test."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-05 14:30:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

> I haven't looked at test runner stuff in general in well over a
 > year.   But IIRC, the usual test architecture is that tests are
 > running in individual processes, and no threads are being used.  
 > The error you show looks like previous test artifacts not being
 > cleaned up.   There needs to be a hard/clear cleanup that works in
 > one of three ways:  the first is that the previous test took place
 > in a transaction that is then fully rolled back.  this is not
 > really appropriate for openstack, not the least of which because
 > MySQL doesn't have transactional DDL so cannot apply to migration
 > tests but also it's a little bit hard to get right.   The next is
 > that DELETE statements are run against all the tables in the schema
 > and then whatever fixture rows need to exist are re-INSERTed.  This
 > is also difficult to get right, and again doesn't apply to
 > migration tests.   The third is the safest and easiest way but has
 > the disadvantage of being slow, which is you drop the whole schema
 > and re-create it all over again on each test.   The two intricacies
 > here are that the schema can either be re-created by running a
 > create_all() over the existing model (fast, works on SQLite), or by
 > running through all the migrations (slow, often doesn't work on
 > SQLite).   Nova has invented an additional system of recreating the
 > schema which is specific to SQLite here: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/tests/fixtures.py#L658
 > 
 > The large number of fixtures you see in oslo_db correspond to all
 > of these different techniques.    The drop and recreate the whole
 > schema approach is likely the most common.   Most services run all
 > their tests on SQLite only, and then only migration tests are run
 > on Postgresql/MySQL using the opportunistic mixin.
 > 
 > I haven't looked at any code as yet because I need to find a large
 > block of time to dedicate to a full run-through of this suite, but
 > you want to start out with tests running only on SQLite except for
 > migration tests, and you want to make sure everything is blown away
 > both database-wise and global-variable-wise at the end of each
 > test.

Yeah, that's what I'm going for. Seem to be making some headway."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-05 14:37:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-05 15:46:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Workflow-1

The fix doesn't necessary need to be in this patch, but if we can make it happen in this stack that would be grand."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-11-14 13:01:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

'}, {'created': '2018-10-31 20:06:45.000000000', 'message': 'Added alembic environment

Added alembic, and created an initial database revision.

For the sake of test with real databases, tools/test-setup.sh is added
so that CI can start up a mysql and/or postgresql database on which to
test migrations.

Those tests will confirm that the models match the migrations so we also
need to remove model files that no longer matter.

Since we no longer need to distinguish among multiple database files, we
can simplify the naming of these files.

Some of the tests are not currently, these are marked in the
test_migrations.py. An additional test, from oslo_db, named
`test_models_sync` is _sometimes_ failing because of the server_default
on consumer generations.

Change-Id: I51ed1e4e7dbb76a3eab23af7d0d106f716059112
'}, {'created': '2018-11-02 10:30:36.000000000', 'message': 'Added alembic environment

Added alembic, and created an initial database revision.

For the sake of test with real databases, tools/test-setup.sh is added
so that CI can start up a mysql and/or postgresql database on which to
test migrations.

Those tests will confirm that the models match the migrations so we also
need to remove model files that no longer matter.

Since we no longer need to distinguish among multiple database files, we
can simplify the naming of these files.

Some of the tests are not currently, these are marked in the
test_migrations.py. An additional test, from oslo_db, named

Added alembic, and created an initial database revision.

For the sake of testing with real databases, tools/test-setup.sh is added
so that CI can start up a mysql and/or postgresql database on which to
test migrations. The OpportunisticDBMixin from oslo_db was originally
used for this, but because of the way placement configures the database
this proved hard to debug and get correct, so we've used something
that leverages the available oslo_db tools, but with more visibility.

Because these tests mix sqlite, mysql and postgresql settings in the
potentially the same process we need a way to insure that global
settings for databsases do not leak into other tests. This is done with
a reset() on the placement db fixture, called by the msyql and
postgresql tests after they run.

Those tests will confirm that the models match the migrations so we also
need to remove model files that no longer matter.

Since we no longer need to distinguish among multiple database files, we
can simplify the naming of these files.

commit_message:
Added alembic environment

Added alembic, and created an initial database revision.

For the sake of testing with real databases, tools/test-setup.sh is added
so that CI can start up a mysql and/or postgresql database on which to
test migrations. The OpportunisticDBMixin from oslo_db was originally
used for this, but because of the way placement configures the database
this proved hard to debug and get correct, so we've used something
that leverages the available oslo_db tools, but with more visibility.

Because these tests mix sqlite, mysql and postgresql settings in the
potentially the same process we need a way to insure that global
settings for databases do not leak into other tests. This is done with
a reset() on the placement db fixture, called by the msyql and
postgresql tests before and after they run. We also need careful
management of that cleanup when these tests are skipped (because db
server or database is not there).

Those tests will confirm that the models match the migrations so we also
need to remove model files that no longer matter.

Since we no longer need to distinguish among multiple database files, we
can simplify the naming of these files.

Co-Authored-By: Chris Dent <cdent@anticdent.org>
Change-Id: I51ed1e4e7dbb76a3eab23af7d0d106f716059112

commit_message:
Add extra volume types to AIO

This change adds example volume types in AIO. It will allow tests to
enter code paths that create volume types and associate QoS specs.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/617052
Change-Id: I0cb77b1958e586e35458368ec00f4f167d031923
(cherry picked from commit 80c7c23a68229b97080a784b6164ea78d79192d4)

commit_message:
Add stack name to env() for OS::TripleO::WorkflowSteps

In I4b576a6e7fbfb18fa13221e2d080bf7876a8303e state information
will be persisted in Swift and the name of the Swift container
should be a function of the Heat stack in case multiple stacks
are deployed. This patch passes the name of the Heat stack to
the Mistral environment so that the workflow may access the
Heat stack name and name the Swift container accordingly.

Change-Id: I995ad32345a39238ffb9cbcf9966dedc60c75ff8
Depends-On: I45916f4d3458dd4de1ae0e0cb680a29d2dcb09f6
Related-Bug: #1769769
(cherry picked from commit d51bd9e1bde10ae1d277fa527564536a92a645f9)

Checked this morning and this wasn't here."}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2018-11-19 15:37:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-11-19 15:52:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-19 11:11:47.000000000', 'message': "Handle unicode characters in migration params

There can be unicode characters in the params for live migration, for
example, the guest domain name in the destination XML. We need to
convert those to bytes when we call migrateToURI3 under python2.

with the error:

  UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters...

Change-Id: I4b34139a3c5e3e2b7cf7cbe50bdf3da3131b9b1c

commit_message:
Handle unicode characters in migration params

There can be unicode characters in the params for live migration, for
example, the guest domain name in the destination XML. We need to
convert those to bytes when we call migrateToURI3 under python2.

The existing code was just calling str() for this, but that will fail
with the error:

  UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters...

We need to encode the unicode characters to do conversion.

The existing unit test wasn't using any unicode characters in its test
data, so this scenario wasn't covered.

Closes-Bug: #1768807

Change-Id: I4b34139a3c5e3e2b7cf7cbe50bdf3da3131b9b1c
(cherry picked from commit f046d8b54009978a3c83939dc190edbc1ebc09ae)

commit_message:
Release sushy 1.7.0

This is the Stein milestone-1 release for sushy to release merged
commits since the last release.

See [1] for more details on the new cycle-with-intermediary library
release changes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135689.html

We plan on processing this release November 1 unless we are told to hold
off, or earlier if we get a +1 from the PTL and/or release liaison
indicating that it is all clear to proceed.

Change-Id: Iac5631958de7df287b6aeb4f9c29ff295f39a3bf
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Bump the timeout for plan creation workflow to 20 minutes

The default plan has grown. Processing of the plan is taking longer on
occasion, so it's reasonable to bump the timeout, instead of it being
razor thin.

Change-Id: Ieec42c2d31c88543922d4c9f01efd62758f9a7fb
Related-Bug: rhbz#1619704

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-11 13:21:04.000000000', 'message': "sahara-image-pack: use curl for tarballs.openstack.org

It seems that wget throws some errors from time to time when getting
content from tarballs.openstack.org.
The errors are SSL-related, maybe some interaction between the SSL libaries
of the libguestfs appliance and the load balancing configuration
of tarballs.openstack.org (SNI-based).
curl seems to be immune, so let's use it.

Story: 2003961
Task: 26890
Change-Id: Ia5793a4be8cde352329e861c46de8c4eeac4312e
(cherry picked from commit 12b270b092a686d94f1b5b4bedb24acffde31932)
"}]
commit_message:
sahara-image-pack: use curl for tarballs.openstack.org

It seems that wget throws some errors from time to time when getting
content from tarballs.openstack.org.
The errors are SSL-related, maybe some interaction between the SSL libaries
of the libguestfs appliance and the load balancing configuration
of tarballs.openstack.org (SNI-based).
curl seems to be immune, so let's use it.

Story: 2003961
Task: 26890
Change-Id: Ia5793a4be8cde352329e861c46de8c4eeac4312e
(cherry picked from commit 12b270b092a686d94f1b5b4bedb24acffde31932)

[{'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-10-17 21:02:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-17 21:31:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

this seems like it is kind of the right idea, but is going to struggle in its current form: the functional tests that use the db expect to be able to do a migration, so most of them are going to fail.

I think you may need to go in a different order. Two ideas:

* do the alembic bits first, somehow constraining the tables used, then remove the old way, changing the functional tests migration handling in the process
* switching the functional tests to not doing a migration at all and doing the create_all thing found in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/600161/ , but if we do that there will need to be some kind of "test of the migrations" (which would be a good thing anyway)

I kind of prefer the latter as it is likely to be faster, but it may break with norms more than desired.

pep8 is also failing, and some files are in this patch that I would have expected to see in the next one (if this patch was working as intended)'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-10-18 15:20:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Delete the old migrations

As the first step to implementing alembic for our data migrations, we
need to get rid of the old migration files.

Change-Id: Ib6ee4895a3c5b18b027f1ac44905dff0e28cdcf8

[{'created': '2018-11-06 11:58:01.000000000', 'message': 'Add py36 tox environment

We already run python3.6 unit tests in CI. Add the py36 environment to
the tox file so that developers with python3.6 available locally can opt
into running that version too.

Change-Id: I28e96e5922b73f270b0e77fff91e4343ad06a852
'}]
commit_message:
Add py36 tox environment

We already run python3.6 unit tests in CI. Add the py36 environment to
the tox file so that developers with python3.6 available locally can opt
into running that version too.

Change-Id: I28e96e5922b73f270b0e77fff91e4343ad06a852

commit_message:
devstack: enable flow based tunnels for sfc

ODL SFC requires flow based tunnels to operate correctly. This is
enabled through a specific property set as an external id in the
OVS database.

Change-Id: I8dc63d8ca223a7d8787236917cf2036ef8b910cc

commit_message:
Add more NSX config parameters

Update dhcp_profile_uuid and metadata_proxy_uuid config params
based on NSX plugin side changes, and also expose more config
parameters that can be used in depoying tripleo with nsx plugin.

Change-Id: I787606f39f1b707211f19415aceb81cda8260d91

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-29 12:02:33.000000000', 'message': "Decoupling number of API and RPC workers for neutron-api

On certain Neutron backends such as OVN where no agents are used,
it's unnecessary to have (so many)RPC workers running. This patch is
decoupling the number of API and RPC workers for neutron server.

In the case that the new NeutronRpcWorkers parameter is not defined,
it'll take the value of NeutronWorkers so that we don't introduce
any regression if some environments don't define it.

Change-Id: I0a3b78947fdeda638d0756f08b577d4351f371e0
Partial-Bug: #1786952
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 0afe46b6f2df4f3b950798a66f170c23ff43dd66)
"}]
commit_message:
Decoupling number of API and RPC workers for neutron-api

On certain Neutron backends such as OVN where no agents are used,
it's unnecessary to have (so many)RPC workers running. This patch is
decoupling the number of API and RPC workers for neutron server.

In the case that the new NeutronRpcWorkers parameter is not defined,
it'll take the value of NeutronWorkers so that we don't introduce
any regression if some environments don't define it.

Change-Id: I0a3b78947fdeda638d0756f08b577d4351f371e0
Partial-Bug: #1786952
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 0afe46b6f2df4f3b950798a66f170c23ff43dd66)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-19 10:59:09.000000000', 'message': 'Enable disablereuse option in Zaqar proxy backend

Modify the Zaqar mod_proxy backend to use use the parameter
disablereuse=On, disabling the ability to reuse connections to the
proxy backend.  This is necessary to prevent reuse of connections by
mod_proxy to the backend Zaqar WebSocket server when the Zaqar
WebSocket server closes the socket on its own, that mod_proxy
occasionally expects to be open.  This creates a new connection with
every request.

Change-Id: Id5f22d8682805566eadd8205a5aa88524ce94b80
Closes-Bug: #1803422
(cherry picked from commit d4c98bd2c615cc3ac6546cea6814b113c352a8d3)
'}]
commit_message:
Enable disablereuse option in Zaqar proxy backend

Modify the Zaqar mod_proxy backend to use use the parameter
disablereuse=On, disabling the ability to reuse connections to the
proxy backend.  This is necessary to prevent reuse of connections by
mod_proxy to the backend Zaqar WebSocket server when the Zaqar
WebSocket server closes the socket on its own, that mod_proxy
occasionally expects to be open.  This creates a new connection with
every request.

Change-Id: Id5f22d8682805566eadd8205a5aa88524ce94b80
Closes-Bug: #1803422
(cherry picked from commit d4c98bd2c615cc3ac6546cea6814b113c352a8d3)

commit_message:
Allow paunch to be called as a python module

Includes a test that we can succesfully call it as a module in order
to avoid regressions.

This is essential fix related to python3 work as the only way to
enforce a specific python interpreter to be used.

Change-Id: If5c4bda5ddc708bfb3701800cea46e89a026fb6e
Story: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/361

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-11 13:09:50.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: make sure octavia flavor gets configured if composable octavia

The octavia service templates configure the octavia flavor through the
controller-worker is deployed on a node other than the controller. Since
this uses docker_puppet_tasks, it is only run on the bootstrap node
which at the moment means the first controller. This patch moves the
flavor creation to the docker API template to make sure the flavor gets
created when deploying worker components in an non-standard role.

Change-Id: Id823672b82ea60f355d1f01068f802567d687da5
'}, {'created': '2018-10-11 18:44:50.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: make sure octavia flavor gets configured if composable octavia

commit_message:
Ensure octavia flavor gets configured if composable octavia

The octavia service templates configure the octavia flavor through the
controller-worker is deployed on a node other than the controller. Since
this uses docker_puppet_tasks, it is only run on the bootstrap node
which at the moment means the first controller. This patch moves the
flavor creation to the docker API template to make sure the flavor gets
created when deploying worker components in an non-standard role.

Closes-Bug: #1797443

Change-Id: Id823672b82ea60f355d1f01068f802567d687da5

commit_message:
Make LBaaS v2 gates non-voting

LBaaS v2 gates are broken due to bug 1801360. Until it is fixed in
python-neutronclient and a new version is released I'm proposing to make
those gates non-voting.

Change-Id: I9b5809f78274aa723cd942c587ad65e599283c0b
Related-Bug: 1801360

commit_message:
Update dependencies to Rocky

Use stable/rocky branch of:

* Kolla
* Kolla ansible
* Bifrost
* IPA
* OpenStack services
* Requirements

Also updates Kolla Ansible inventory template.

The seed deploy job has been made non-voting and non-gating, because we
are waiting for bifrost change https://review.openstack.org/#/c/618740
to merge, be released, and for the kolla bifrost image to use the new
package.

Change-Id: Id5e7fdbd196f96e1e75ffc68bc93aab18fa38aa7
Story: 2001864
Task: 27798
Depends-On: I58e4f951d4a3dd89e0784fd82d8a62dbba374f79

messages: [{'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2018-11-19 11:18:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-11-19 15:36:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-11-19 18:07:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nWe need to run pep8 in the gate, otherwise it'll regress again."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-19 11:18:17.000000000', 'message': 'Upgrade hacking fixed conf.py linting

One conf.py was failing to pass falke8 and the other one was excluded.
Removed exclusion and fixed these filex as this is a more future proof
approach.

Before this change a clean clone of this repository would have failed
on `tox -e pep8`.

Change-Id: Ib8337aa6129acb515e33846c0635b582d1eedb8b
'}]
commit_message:
Upgrade hacking fixed conf.py linting

One conf.py was failing to pass falke8 and the other one was excluded.
Removed exclusion and fixed these filex as this is a more future proof
approach.

Before this change a clean clone of this repository would have failed
on `tox -e pep8`.

Change-Id: Ib8337aa6129acb515e33846c0635b582d1eedb8b

commit_message:
expose rbac db objects in setup.cfg

This patch adds the NeutronRbacObject and RbacNeutronDbObjectMixin to
the neutron.objects entry point of setup.cfg so consumers can load them
using neutron-lib's object registry.

Change-Id: Ifc9fb83b2266d2e4b551acb077a2d14a5dc0c652

commit_message:
Fix indentation issue

Change Icde6c61a0b26741946d079b2b00475de34722bea introduced a couple of
indentation mistakes.

Change-Id: I47756939fd933788b85bbd141d3c3bd870445efa

commit_message:
libvirt: get_inventory => update_provider_tree

Port the libvirt compute driver's get_inventory method to
update_provider_tree.

Change-Id: I60810aeebc07bae7195ea9433d923c479505f6ed

subject: Wait for resources to become available
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-06 16:40:29.000000000', 'message': 'Wait for resources to become available

This will wait for any resources that are created to become available
before exiting the script. This allows you to avoid a race condition
where a server could be created before the resource tracker had been
updated with the new resources; server creation would fail.

Change-Id: I57f8c93cb1ebbc284b96ef1ced2c4edd59b27795

commit_message:
Wait for resources to become available

This will wait for any resources that are created to become available
before exiting the script. This allows you to avoid a race condition
where a server could be created before the resource tracker had been
updated with the new resources; server creation would fail.

Change-Id: I57f8c93cb1ebbc284b96ef1ced2c4edd59b27795
Story: 2004274
Task: 27823
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/617642

subject: Use ensure_connection to prevent loss of connection error logs
messages:
[{'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2018-11-05 21:07:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2018-11-05 21:07:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2018-11-06 14:52:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 8770, 'date': '2018-11-06 15:00:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is a fundamental change to the way connections are established in the rabbit driver - I'd like folks to take a moment to review it.

See the original bug report - there are no logs generated when connections fail due to SSL mis-configuration.  The driver simply logs "Connecting to <blah>..." then goes silent.

While debugging this I found that the autoretry method would attempt to access the "default_channel" property of the connection, which would trigger bringing up the connection before attempting to call the method passed to autoretry (connection.connect() in this case).  The triggered connection setup code is not passed the "on_error" function we pass to autoretry.  Thus no logging on ssl failure.

From reading the kombu docs I believe that the proper way to ensure the connection is established is not to call autoretry but to call ensure_connection on the kombu connection.  I infer this since the methods passed to autoretry are expected to be passed a channel, which connection.connect() does not take.'}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2018-11-06 22:09:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20523, 'date': '2018-11-19 16:11:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

Change-Id: I31e3f83304c0780cfd380aa63ec2962c3c28ec78
Closes-Bug: #1801011
'}]

Task: 27954

subject: Added test_service_providers_rbac test case
messages:
[{'account_id': 26210, 'date': '2017-12-04 20:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2017-12-05 00:23:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Thanks, Nishad, but these API endpoints aren't defined in Tempest; they are defined in a separate repository [0] (keystone-tempest-plugin). This means that we can't support these tests in Patrole because Patrole itself is a Tempest plugin. There was a discussion a while back when it was decided that cross-Tempest plugin interaction wasn't ideal. The path forward is to create a stable library for Patrole which can be consumed externally by other services, but we're a long way from there. Alternatively, if we can move the service providers client into Tempest (and out of the keystone-tempest-plugin) then we can support these tests. We can discuss that option with QA this week, although that would also require communicating with the Keystone team too.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/keystone-tempest-plugin/blob/master/keystone_tempest_plugin/services/identity/v3/service_providers_client.py"}, {'account_id': 25571, 'date': '2017-12-13 09:59:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 25695, 'date': '2017-12-13 10:08:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 25695, 'date': '2017-12-13 10:19:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Move zuul project definition to top of file

This change moves the project definition for the keystone zuul
jobs to the top of the file. This allows for easier reading of
which jobs are defined from a top-down view as well as allows
for all in-repo job definitions to be put below.

Change-Id: Id511195dac6250c59de618f26a7bf850547ac40e

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-10 01:40:02.000000000', 'message': 'Install libpython2.7

One of the pip packages we install, uwsgi, requires libpython2.7
to be installed. It is normally pulled in as a dependency by either
pip_install or galera_client as an apt-recommends package. When
recommends are disabled or reduced package lists are used, uwsgi
fails to start on the cinder-api container because libpython2.7.so.1.0
is missing.

Example error:
Aug  8 17:30:36 aio1-cinder-api-container-f74e98f2 uwsgi[3188]:
/openstack/venvs/cinder-17.0.8/bin/uwsgi: error while loading shared
libraries: libpython2.7.so.1.0: cannot open shared object file: No
such file or directory

Change-Id: I10e30da2ef1fa35e8f55be3f2248e7c538bd3835
(cherry picked from commit 977b3f326577a41967d6a1eb2a226f777a17af95)
'}]
commit_message:
Install libpython2.7

One of the pip packages we install, uwsgi, requires libpython2.7
to be installed. It is normally pulled in as a dependency by either
pip_install or galera_client as an apt-recommends package. When
recommends are disabled or reduced package lists are used, uwsgi
fails to start on the cinder-api container because libpython2.7.so.1.0
is missing.

Example error:
Aug  8 17:30:36 aio1-cinder-api-container-f74e98f2 uwsgi[3188]:
/openstack/venvs/cinder-17.0.8/bin/uwsgi: error while loading shared
libraries: libpython2.7.so.1.0: cannot open shared object file: No
such file or directory

Change-Id: I10e30da2ef1fa35e8f55be3f2248e7c538bd3835
(cherry picked from commit 977b3f326577a41967d6a1eb2a226f777a17af95)

commit_message:
Fix the horizon failed to start

Currently, Horzion container fails to start when enabled designate,
murano, magnum and so on. This patch is to fix it.

Change-Id: I32da6dc1a65d3bfcaa59b4c9136e389af1f9b551
Closes-Bug: #1744428
(cherry picked from commit 8ab42604186064d61a6b9a024a37ade1f885f204)

commit_message:
Add OS_USERNAME and OS_PROJECT_NAME to PS1

This patch adds OS_USERNAME and OS_PROJECT_NAME to the PS1 of the
command prompt. The should help reduce confusion about which user
and project is being used to interact with the openstack. The
update is needed here because stackrc and overcloudrc* only update
PS1 once.

Change-Id: I6c6ce7f1a631cd31363839e44c8d889c02790ddd

commit_message:
Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

This is a mechanically generated patch to add a unit test job running
under Python 3.7 and drop the Python 3.5 unit test job.

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial. Now that
we have Bionic nodes supporting python3.6 and python3.7, let's switch
to testing with python3.7 in addition to python3.6 in Stein and
beyond.

See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135626.html

Change-Id: I5de13616938e41ab7fba22c1e710d3bac32c8651
Story: #2004073
Task: #27450

commit_message:
Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

This is a mechanically generated patch to add a unit test job running
under Python 3.7 and drop the Python 3.5 unit test job.

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial. Now that
we have Bionic nodes supporting python3.6 and python3.7, let's switch
to testing with python3.7 in addition to python3.6 in Stein and
beyond.

See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135626.html

Change-Id: I56997c4acd335e924af8b85c89ce782172e40d91
Story: #2004073
Task: #27459

commit_message:
Change python3.5 job to python3.7 job on Stein+

This is a mechanically generated patch to add a unit test job running
under Python 3.7 and drop the Python 3.5 unit test job.

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial. Now that
we have Bionic nodes supporting python3.6 and python3.7, let's switch
to testing with python3.7 in addition to python3.6 in Stein and
beyond.

See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135626.html

Change-Id: I9c9d3c5b3507c4e2b9dcef4976dacead2fb2d82a
Story: #2004073

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17776, 'date': '2017-12-11 21:37:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2017-12-12 08:45:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

I wonder if there is any way to test that it will not break anything in neutron or some stadium projects without merging it.
AFAIK test patch with depends-on tag will not help because neutron-lib is installed from stable release, right?
Maybe someone has got any idea about that?'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2017-12-12 14:02:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Testing with neutron/master is possible using the "dummy depends on approach" [1]. Basically this patch can depend on a neutron patch that uses the lib change and when run the legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src should pull in neutron/master + the dummy neutron change and run with it.


As far as testing other stadium projects:
- We do have the periodic jobs [2] that run on neutron-lib/master. So worst case is we land this patch and something breaks that surfaces in the periodic jobs. We could then just revert/fix this before we release the next lib version.
- You can always test manually on your workstation (in some cases). Just use the .tox env to install neutron-lib/master with this change into the .tox env your testing with.
- I'm not sure if depends-on works from other projects (using stable branches) now that we are on zuul v3. It would be good to know this for sure.


[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/doc/source/contributor/review-guidelines.rst
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/doc/source/contributor/releasing.rst'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2017-12-12 14:29:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

> Testing with neutron/master is possible using the "dummy depends on
 > approach" [1]. Basically this patch can depend on a neutron patch
 > that uses the lib change and when run the legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src
 > should pull in neutron/master + the dummy neutron change and run
 > with it.

Thanks for this tip. I didn't know about this dummy depends on approach  :)

 > 
 > 
 > As far as testing other stadium projects:
 > - We do have the periodic jobs [2] that run on neutron-lib/master.
 > So worst case is we land this patch and something breaks that
 > surfaces in the periodic jobs. We could then just revert/fix this
 > before we release the next lib version.

Thanks, that could be enough IMO :)

 > - You can always test manually on your workstation (in some cases).
 > Just use the .tox env to install neutron-lib/master with this
 > change into the .tox env your testing with.

I know but I wanted to know if there are any possible ways to check such changes in gate also

 > - I'm not sure if depends-on works from other projects (using
 > stable branches) now that we are on zuul v3. It would be good to
 > know this for sure.
 > 
 > 
 > [1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/doc/source/contributor/review-guidelines.rst
 > [2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/doc/source/contributor/releasing.rst'}, {'account_id': 17776, 'date': '2018-04-16 08:47:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(1 comment)

@boden, @slawek : can this be moved forward?'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-04-16 15:05:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

IMHO it can, but as per our previous comments I was hoping some testing was going to be done to ensure it didn't break any consumers."}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-05-05 22:04:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I would also like to see at least some dummy test patch to check that all works with this change :)'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-11-01 20:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

Yes, add allocation-pools and I think this will be LGTM-ready.'}, {'account_id': 23858, 'date': '2018-11-12 09:32:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Published edit on patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 23858, 'date': '2018-11-12 09:32:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23858, 'date': '2018-11-12 09:35:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

So maybe I didnt understand it properly.
But I created a test patch in neutron/master and linked it to this patch ( maybe I understood incorrectly ). I have updated the tests in that patch to verify if a full fledged IPv6 Address would be converted to the canonical format or not. There is no other specific usage in neutron for this change in neutron-lib.'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-11-13 13:24:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I think this is setup to properly test given the inventory [1] is showing the neutron patch depended on herein.


However do we also need to update the API reference for this to indicate the new conversion?


[1] http://logs.openstack.org/80/493280/11/check/tempest-full/fb6660d/zuul-info/inventory.yaml'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-11-13 22:56:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 23858, 'date': '2018-11-14 05:02:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

@boden : Not sure about that. Though releasenotes were updated in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/357670/, but whether the API Ref needs to be updated is a question for me as well. @slaweq/@nate/@mlavalle: any inputs?'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-11-15 09:02:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

> @boden : Not sure about that. Though releasenotes were updated in
 > https://review.openstack.org/#/c/357670/, but whether the API Ref
 > needs to be updated is a question for me as well. @slaweq/@nate/@mlavalle:
 > any inputs?

IMO it could be mentioned in description of "cidr", "allocation_pools" and "gateway_ip" parameters in https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/?expanded=create-subnet-detail#subnets but if others think that it's not necessary, I'm fine with this also :)'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-11-15 11:10:09.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review-1 by Slawek Kaplonski <skaplons@redhat.com>
'}, {'account_id': 23858, 'date': '2018-11-15 11:15:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

As discussed with Slaweq, I will remove the Depends-On now as neutron-lib is able to work properly with Neutron.
@Boden: Request you to please suggest if any other action needs to be taken.

Also need inputs for the API-Ref'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-11-15 13:21:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

I guess I'm fine with the API ref as-is...
As mention though, the depends on needs to be removed from this patch since that was for testing purposes."}, {'account_id': 23858, 'date': '2018-11-16 05:26:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-11-16 08:36:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2018-11-16 15:09:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-11-19 13:59:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add ipv6 canonical address converter to API

This patch takes care of converting of IPv6 address
for gateway-ip, cidr and allocation-pools to canonical
format.

Closes-Bug:1531103
Change-Id: Ibef0bd9a2f7b7dd8ddccc183f17aa31e426c7fd0

commit_message:
Trivial: use string for exception message

Exception messages are expected to be strings. Some Nova exception
handlers will fail when encountering wrapped exceptions.

This change fixes the only occurrence of this issue.

Change-Id: If35f7b99f9c0b9f0edd614dc96842549e6ac19c1
Closes-Bug: #1801713

commit_message:
Document distributed lock configuration

We're now relying on distributed locks in order to prevent race
conditions that affect instance failover handling.

This change documents the required configuration updates and
prerequisites.

Change-Id: Ic08b28ac16faea673838aa2dc05c1dd70806280e

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-09 14:24:53.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Improve clustered instance failover handling

Instances can bounce between hosts many times in a short interval,
especially if the CSVs go down (as much as 20 times in less than 2
minutes).

We're not handling this properly. The failover handling logic is
prone to race conditions, as multiple hosts may attempt to claim
the instance, which will end up in an inconsistent state.

We're introducing distributed locks, preventing races between hosts.
At the same time, we're validating the events, as the instances can
move again by the time we process the event.

The distributed lock backend will have to be configured (TODO: add
a release note and update the documentation).

Change-Id: I3dbdcf208bb7a96bd516b41e4725a5fcb37280d6
"}, {'created': '2018-10-10 07:16:16.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Improve clustered instance failover handling

commit_message:
Improve clustered instance failover handling

Instances can bounce between hosts many times in a short interval,
especially if the CSVs go down (as much as 20 times in less than 2
minutes).

We're not handling this properly. The failover handling logic is
prone to race conditions, as multiple hosts may attempt to claim
the instance, which will end up in an inconsistent state.

We're introducing distributed locks, preventing races between hosts.
At the same time, we're validating the events, as the instances can
move again by the time we process the event.

The distributed lock backend will have to be configured.

At the same time, we're now waiting for "pending" cluster groups,
which may not even be registered in Hyper-V, so any action we take
on the VM would fail.

Closes-Bug: #1795299
Closes-Bug: #1796673

Change-Id: I3dbdcf208bb7a96bd516b41e4725a5fcb37280d6

commit_message:
Disable wmi object caching by default

Due to the known issues related to WMI object caching, it's safer
if we just disable it by default.

Change-Id: If859917af9a185fc612231002d252c9e0ac6ddd3
Related-Bug: #1801701

commit_message:
Refresh admin doc

What this patch done:

1. Paste is removed from Keystone. The healthcheck middleware
now is enabled by default.
2. Role supports `description` property now.
3. `reader` and `member` role are added to bootstrap command.

Update the related doc.

Change-Id: Ic49d3b09cf0df8bc4b1096349e36bdee2f1da0ca

commit_message:
Prevent standalone upgrade to run on rocky patch.

We can't deploy standalone queens, which prevents us from testing the
standalone upgrade to rocky.

Change-Id: Ieaacffbc5bab18750b6b8b1ea59b4d0c87867fdf
Closes-Bug: #1803969

subject: Add started_at and finished_at to task execution.
messages:
[{'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2018-10-03 20:35:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2018-10-04 07:40:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2018-10-04 11:59:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2018-10-04 20:50:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-10-08 05:11:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Goo point, thanks Oleg for the work. Instead of tasks, I think, it would make more sense (and probably significantly less coding) to add this info to action executions. The tasks with the rerun flag and loose coupling between the engine and the executor, cannot provide accurate info anyway.'}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2018-10-08 08:13:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Goo point, thanks Oleg for the work. Instead of tasks, I think, it
 > would make more sense (and probably significantly less coding) to
 > add this info to action executions. The tasks with the rerun flag
 > and loose coupling between the engine and the executor, cannot
 > provide accurate info anyway.
We can't set in to action execution. This solution would not cover this cases:
1. If we have any wait-before or wait-after, it would not be included. 
2. If we had subworkflow and it has waiting before start (e.g. join all), we wouldn't have any information about actual time. 
The main idiom is very simple - the sum of task's actual execution time equals to workflow execution time. In your suggested way it would be wrong and kinda confused."}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2018-10-08 08:38:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

One more case: if task has retries, action execution will recreate every time, so again we will not have enough information'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-10-08 09:15:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> > Goo point, thanks Oleg for the work. Instead of tasks, I think,
 > it
 > > would make more sense (and probably significantly less coding) to
 > > add this info to action executions. The tasks with the rerun flag
 > > and loose coupling between the engine and the executor, cannot
 > > provide accurate info anyway.
 > We can't set in to action execution. This solution would not cover
 > this cases:
 > 1. If we have any wait-before or wait-after, it would not be
 > included.
 > 2. If we had subworkflow and it has waiting before start (e.g. join
 > all), we wouldn't have any information about actual time.
 > The main idiom is very simple - the sum of task's actual execution
 > time equals to workflow execution time. In your suggested way it
 > would be wrong and kinda confused.

I understand why you suggest the task level, however, due to the rerun feature, it still is a partial solution.  The action-execution is the actual execution of the action :) This is where execution can be measured the most precisely, if that is needed.

So my arguments against this form of this feature:
1) creates new mutable fields that in fact belong to an execution and not really the actual task. This is accentuated in your implementation too with the introduction of the rerun flag in several APIs. (The task is already a confusing construct, I'd try to go for cleaning it up instead of making use of the clutter.)
2) the problem that there is no UI and console support for showing aggregated info should be handled separately. (CloudFlow can add a feature to show the execution times from the action-execution. In this respect there should be no functional difference between adding the info to the task or the action-execution.
3) the thing you implemented is exactly what I proposed but it belongs to the execution, not the tas. And it can be overwritten with updates resulting from rerun.
4) In both cases, if the timing logic is added to the engine, we measure the "dispatch time" (when the request to start the action was sent out to executors) and the "result receive time." But let's not get this deep in the rabbit hole :)'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-10-10 05:53:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

Well, in my opinion the patch is very clean and accurately implements the idea. Regarding what Andras says, I partially agree but I would split these two things: actions and tasks. IMO the actual task execution time is valueable. As well as the actual action execution time. So we might want to do the same with actions. I also agree that the current implementation doesn't account RPC dispatching etc. etc. but IMO that's OK because it tracks down the time points when engine started processing a task and finished with it. That's good anyway. RPC and all other mechanism can be considered internal parts of the engine execution mechanism. So I think the current impl is totally OK."}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-10-10 06:07:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

Renat, I'm very much against introducing mutable fields again. So I remove my vote and don't support it either."}, {'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2018-10-21 13:00:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2018-10-25 15:55:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2018-11-09 14:33:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-11-19 06:24:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-11-19 06:28:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Ok, let's get this rolling."}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2018-11-19 08:27:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-11-19 11:40:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add started_at and finished_at to task execution.

Sometimes it is very important to know exact time of task execution, but using fields
created_at and updated_at is incorrect, because in this case duration will consist
of not only Running time.
That new fields solve this problem.

Change-Id: I15be0648a0346f5b3dc9ef4a1b330a6c0e818385
Implements: blueprint mistral-add-started-finished-at
Signed-off-by: Oleg Ovcharuk <vgvoleg@gmail.com>

[{'created': '2018-11-18 15:34:48.000000000', 'message': "Update tox.ini

Split up doc8 commandline, use separate doc8 section for it to better
visualize what we do. Remove things that are not needed for this repo
since doc8 only checks below doc directory, include also README file for
checking.

Add -d option to sphinx-build so that the doctrees directory does not
get published.

Fix also two occurences of UTF-8 characters in intro.rst, we can use
ASCII everywhere and use a normal '.

Change-Id: Ib81ccba6ad92e2d07ff96d48746696454986d3ed
"}]
commit_message:
Update tox.ini

Split up doc8 commandline, use separate doc8 section for it to better
visualize what we do. Remove things that are not needed for this repo
since doc8 only checks below doc directory, include also README file for
checking.

Add -d option to sphinx-build so that the doctrees directory does not
get published.

Fix also two occurences of UTF-8 characters in intro.rst, we can use
ASCII everywhere and use a normal '.

Change-Id: Ib81ccba6ad92e2d07ff96d48746696454986d3ed
