revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-12 06:40:24.000000000', 'message': '(WIP)DVR: Centralized FloatingIPs are not cleared after migration.

With DVR routers, if a port is associated with a FloatingIP,
before it is used by a VM, the FloatingIP will be initially
started at the Network Node SNAT Namespace, since the port
is not bound to any host.

Then when the port is attached to a VM, the port gets its
host binding, and then the FloatingIP setup should be migrated
to the Compute host and the original FloatingIP in the Network
Node SNAT Namespace should be cleared.

But the original FloatingIP setup in SNAT Namespace was not
cleared by the agent.

This patch addresses the issue.

Change-Id: I55a16bcc0020087aa1abe76f5bc85cd64ccdaecd
Closes-Bug: #1796491
'}, {'created': '2018-10-12 23:13:28.000000000', 'message': 'DVR: Centralized FloatingIPs are not cleared after migration.

commit_message:
DVR: Centralized FloatingIPs are not cleared after migration.

With DVR routers, if a port is associated with a FloatingIP,
before it is used by a VM, the FloatingIP will be initially
started at the Network Node SNAT Namespace, since the port
is not bound to any host.

Then when the port is attached to a VM, the port gets its
host binding, and then the FloatingIP setup should be migrated
to the Compute host and the original FloatingIP in the Network
Node SNAT Namespace should be cleared.

But the original FloatingIP setup in SNAT Namespace was not
cleared by the agent.

This patch addresses the issue.

Change-Id: I55a16bcc0020087aa1abe76f5bc85cd64ccdaecd
Closes-Bug: #1796491

commit_message:
Update the min version of tox to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0. Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I1dce1ed6b548e109578ce35f4729febf911cef03

Changed how the Target Hosts identified the Backup Host. Now you use backup_server_hostgroup to specify the name of the host group that contains the Backup Host (and if more than one exists, it picks the first one). I changed this behavior because the tasks were having issues working with tripleo-ansible-inventory, but now you can use a static or a dynamic inventory.'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2018-09-25 14:42:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

> (1 comment)
I think Alex's remark still holds for create_new_db.sh.j2 ,
I don't think we ship mysql_install_db in the overcloud nodes.

in tripleo-heat-templates, we have a similar requirement during major upgrades, where we might need to run mysql_upgrade [1].
We do so by creating a transient container with bind-mounts the the host's directory and run mysql commands from that container.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/docker/services/pacemaker/database/mysql.yaml#L495"}, {'account_id': 17126, 'date': '2018-09-25 15:38:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

But it's still available on the mysql container, right? Because the Ansible tasks run the create_new_db.sh script inside a temporary container, not on the physical host.

 > major upgrades, where we might need to run mysql_upgrade [1].

Yep, that's similar to what I'm doing too:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/604439/4/tasks/restore_galera.yml@144

Is there something I need to correct here?"}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2018-09-26 08:01:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17126, 'date': '2018-10-06 10:22:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

Also there's some changes I've discussed with dciabrin that I'm looking to implement as well, mostly around replication checks before the backup and after the restore."}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-10-08 15:10:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17126, 'date': '2018-10-08 23:36:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> (1 comment)

So when you have a blank database, the clustercheck credentials are not there yet. If you move the /etc/sysconfig/clustercheck file, the clustercheck script defaults to using the root user and no password. If you leave /etc/sysconfig/clustercheck as is, galera will report access errors.

With regards to the document you linked, that works fine for systemd-based overclouds. However, for a container-based overcloud, doing a cleanup doesn't restart the container, so kolla doesn't create the new config files, which means both clustercheck and .my.conf don't get regenerated after you change the files.

I could change it so that you unmanage the galera resources and restart the containers directly, but disabling and enabling galera seemed like a simpler method. That said, I'm not tied to this method and willing to follow consensus on what the best way to do it is."}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-10-09 02:00:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> > (1 comment)
 > 
 > So when you have a blank database, the clustercheck credentials are
 > not there yet. If you move the /etc/sysconfig/clustercheck file,
 > the clustercheck script defaults to using the root user and no
 > password. If you leave /etc/sysconfig/clustercheck as is, galera
 > will report access errors.
 > 
 > With regards to the document you linked, that works fine for
 > systemd-based overclouds. However, for a container-based overcloud,
 > doing a cleanup doesn't restart the container, so kolla doesn't
 > create the new config files, which means both clustercheck and
 > .my.conf don't get regenerated after you change the files.
 > 
 > I could change it so that you unmanage the galera resources and
 > restart the containers directly, but disabling and enabling galera
 > seemed like a simpler method. That said, I'm not tied to this
 > method and willing to follow consensus on what the best way to do
 > it is.

Keeping in mind I've been super clumsy with my thinking today and I may very well be missing something, at least the general order of steps I use is that as soon as you create the new, blank database, you run the create user / grants for clustercheck and root back in to the database directly in the next step; in this case this would have to be in the scope of the commands you're running in the temporary container.   then you hit pacemaker to re-enable the normal galera container and it should come right up, there's no need to have moved away the clustercheck or ~root/.my.cnf files.  then you restore the full set of data and grants."}, {'account_id': 17126, 'date': '2018-10-09 02:17:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> > > (1 comment)
 > Keeping in mind I've been super clumsy with my thinking today and I
 > may very well be missing something, at least the general order of
 > steps I use is that as soon as you create the new, blank database,
 > you run the create user / grants for clustercheck and root back in
 > to the database directly in the next step; in this case this would
 > have to be in the scope of the commands you're running in the
 > temporary container. then you hit pacemaker to re-enable the
 > normal galera container and it should come right up, there's no
 > need to have moved away the clustercheck or ~root/.my.cnf files. 
 > then you restore the full set of data and grants.

I think I get what you're saying. If I understand correctly, you're suggesting I should use the temporary container to:

1. init the blank database
2. start mysqld within the container
3. Set clustercheck and root password

Then:

1. Get rid of the temporary container
2. Enable galera
3. Import data and grants
4. Success!

Is that right? If so, then I agree, and it should speed the process up."}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-10-09 02:20:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

that would be it yeah, it should simplify the recipe and also yeah I don't like watching pacemaker re-bootstrap galera a lot, it always makes me a little nervous :)"}, {'account_id': 17126, 'date': '2018-10-09 15:43:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 17126, 'date': '2018-10-09 15:47:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> that would be it yeah, it should simplify the recipe and also yeah
 > I don't like watching pacemaker re-bootstrap galera a lot, it
 > always makes me a little nervous :)

Added a new patch that incorporates the new workflow. The create_new_db.sh.j2 script now contains commands that run on the container to:

1. Start mysqld_safe 
2. Wait until it accepts connections
3. Create the clustercheck@localhost user
4. Set clustercheck's password back to the original and give PROVIDE grants
5. Set the root password back to the original

Thanks for the advice, Michael. It's a big improvement!"}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2018-10-10 17:20:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

looks great thanks!'}, {'account_id': 17126, 'date': '2018-10-16 05:21:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2018-10-24 21:14:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-10-24 21:17:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20775, 'date': '2018-11-15 09:15:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-11-15 17:08:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Adding Backup and Restore Operations

These are a set of tasks to help facilitate backup and restore operations.
This includes preparing an external backup host, configuring SSH for
rsync, and some initial tasks for backing up and restoring a containerized
galera cluster. This should lay the foundation for further backup and
restore tasks.

Change-Id: If5c11956291205cd04a6ef9bdb3d221fcd970f24

commit_message:
Replace call to map-project-name script with rdopkg

The map-project-name script has not been used by DLRN for a long
while, since it moved to using "rdopkg findpkg" to map project names
to package names. We should do the same in tripleo.sh, so the
unmaintained script can be removed.

Change-Id: Ibd9d71043dc92c924ba0cdd17ca1ea03e63bb7af

commit_message:
Clone cached action definitions

* Once in a while we get DetachedInstanceError for action definitions
  and it happens when they are fetched from cache. We must always
  clone persistent objects before caching them.

Change-Id: I1d0cffea6775eb258dcefc0dbb8a6ee18effe597
Closes-Bug: #1803528

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-06 23:08:16.000000000', 'message': 'For ironic-pxe use syslinux-tftpboot package instead of syslinux

For portability, the syslinux-tftpboot package should be used instead of
syslinux as it contains the same tftp server content and can be used
on both x86_64 and ppc architectures.

Change-Id: I9fd50e5312327da828d32e37a3ecf5e290485ca1
Closes-Bug: 1801824
(cherry picked from commit 0af07a54661f6a4046c154f3ca664f13ecd2c195)
'}]
commit_message:
For ironic-pxe use syslinux-tftpboot package instead of syslinux

For portability, the syslinux-tftpboot package should be used instead of
syslinux as it contains the same tftp server content and can be used
on both x86_64 and ppc architectures.

Change-Id: I9fd50e5312327da828d32e37a3ecf5e290485ca1
Closes-Bug: 1801824
(cherry picked from commit 0af07a54661f6a4046c154f3ca664f13ecd2c195)

commit_message:
Deal with py2-py3 payload switch during upgrade-charm

Rebuild charm with latest charms.openstack updates for the
default upgrade-charm handler.

This ensures that the payload execution switch from py2->py3
at OpenStack Rocky is implemented during the charm upgrade
process.

Change-Id: Ifb8570ab85b2c60229a7342dedb228046dc9208b
Closes-Bug: 1803451

Closes-Bug: 1803451

commit_message:
Deal with py2-py3 payload switch during upgrade-charm

Switch to using the default upgrade-charm handler as provided
by charms.openstack and associated layers.

This ensures that the payload execution switch from py2->py3
at OpenStack Rocky is implemented during the charm upgrade
process.

Change-Id: Id2ab577f65c1937bcbbc06a704a8385655de3c57
Closes-Bug: 1803451

commit_message:
Removes checks for branch and current-tripleo/dev

In Rocky and Queens current-tripleo and current branches exist, so there
is no reason not to allow installing those repos.

Change-Id: I9dd7dc0408005c0c9f3df73a7fb57754620096ff
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-07 16:20:02.000000000', 'message': "Deprecate all Neutron LBaaS code

The Neutron LBaaS project was deprecated in Queens and will
be removed in a future release.

Please see here for all information about the deprecation [1].

The Octavia project [2] was borne out of Neutron LBaaS and replaces
all it's functionality and currently supports integration with
Neutron LBaaS as well to allow a migration between the two solutions.

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Neutron/LBaaS/Deprecation
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/octavia/latest/reference/introduction.html

Change-Id: Ic3899f1366cad935545e9567f774f74f228b5800
"}]
commit_message:
Deprecate all Neutron LBaaS code

The Neutron LBaaS project was deprecated in Queens and will
be removed in a future release.

Please see here for all information about the deprecation [1].

The Octavia project [2] was borne out of Neutron LBaaS and replaces
all it's functionality and currently supports integration with
Neutron LBaaS as well to allow a migration between the two solutions.

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Neutron/LBaaS/Deprecation
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/octavia/latest/reference/introduction.html

Change-Id: Ic3899f1366cad935545e9567f774f74f228b5800

commit_message:
Reset ceph-ansible to the current HEAD of stable-3.1

* Instead of pointing at v3.2.0beta1-130, use the current HEAD of
  stable-3.1.
* Add a release note detailing specific considerations
  related to this change.
* Bump openstack_release to 18.1.0.

Change-Id: Ibd8f64d9889009cf6e80b92254fd580ff559b1be
Closes-Bug: 1802195

subject: Deal with py2-py3 migration during charm upgrade
messages: [{'account_id': 935, 'date': '2018-11-15 12:25:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12549, 'date': '2018-11-15 15:57:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-15 12:25:39.000000000', 'message': 'Deal with py2-py3 migration during charm upgrade

On charm upgrade the charm may switch to py3 packages. If so, ensure
the old py2 packages are purged after any new packages have been
installed.  If packages where removed during the upgrade, then
restart all services to pickup any py2->py3 switches.

Change-Id: I8a17f679e85448680ab0b1f5ae362ef7a65b035c
Closes-Bug: 1803451
'}]
commit_message:
Deal with py2-py3 migration during charm upgrade

On charm upgrade the charm may switch to py3 packages. If so, ensure
the old py2 packages are purged after any new packages have been
installed.  If packages where removed during the upgrade, then
restart all services to pickup any py2->py3 switches.

Change-Id: I8a17f679e85448680ab0b1f5ae362ef7a65b035c
Closes-Bug: 1803451

commit_message:
Deal with py2-py3 payload switch during upgrade-charm

Switch to using the default upgrade-charm handler as provided
by charms.openstack and associated layers.

This ensures that the payload execution switch from py2->py3
at OpenStack Rocky is implemented during the charm upgrade
process.

Change-Id: I5e4b8df8ecf1829965952f85a0b5f69729f9f12c
Closes-Bug: 1803451

commit_message:
Deal with py2-py3 payload switch during upgrade-charm

Switch to using the default upgrade-charm handler as provided
by charms.openstack and associated layers.

This ensures that the payload execution switch from py2->py3
at OpenStack Rocky is implemented during the charm upgrade
process.

Change-Id: I8dc19abe813fb78f16cfb0abdbb40cf2ee9a4e6e
Closes-Bug: 1803451

commit_message:
Deal with py2-py3 migration during charm upgrade

On charm upgrade the charm may switch to py3 packages. If so, ensure
the old py2 packages are purged after any new packages have been
installed.  If packages where removed during the upgrade, then
restart all services to pickup any py2->py3 switches.

Change-Id: I9acd536c437ff9d8c6a7056ac255aa4b6de62673
Closes-Bug: 1803451

commit_message:
Deal with py2-py3 payload switch during upgrade-charm

Switch to using the default upgrade-charm handler as provided
by charms.openstack and associated layers.

This ensures that the payload execution switch from py2->py3
at OpenStack Rocky is implemented during the charm upgrade
process.

Change-Id: I7b4b785321ff42b656160b8c6c604bc816ca913c
Closes-Bug: 1803451

commit_message:
Purge old packages on upgrade-charm

On charm upgrade the charm may switch to py3 packages. If so, ensure
the old py2 packages are purged. If the purge occurs then restart
services.

Change-Id: Iddfff1c7ce929776c294034706305f5d77ae9ade
Closes-Bug: 1803451

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-18 10:42:58.000000000', 'message': "Use os_workers fact as the default for swift server processes

Use os_workers instead of 'auto' as the default. This would
limit the number of worker processes.

Change-Id: I69f51bb38f1307cf4b750e5ffb394eb215df1d9e
"}, {'created': '2018-10-22 04:53:24.000000000', 'message': "Set hierdata for swift server workers conditionally

If not set, it would use the default os_workers fact instead of 'auto'
and limit the number of worker processes.

commit_message:
Set hierdata for swift server workers conditionally

If not set, it would use the default os_workers fact instead of 'auto'
and limit the number of worker processes.

Change-Id: I69f51bb38f1307cf4b750e5ffb394eb215df1d9e

commit_message:
Purge old packages on upgrade-charm

On charm upgrade the charm may switch to py3 packages. If so, ensure
the old py2 packages are purged. If the purge occurs then restart
services.

Change-Id: I23812e518d5d0ba64dff33ac8d704b8b0f829b7e
Closes-Bug: 1803451

commit_message:
Adapt to changed resource class names

Before the final merge of the minimum bandwidth resource classes
they got renamed in Nova and Placement. So we have to adapt.

The previous names were never released or used in any other way
outside of WIP patches, so there's no upgrade impact.

Change-Id: Ib81d3a6b312ab7d63df9b5dc97c20d32c3fb214c
Partial-Bug: #1578989
See-Also: I996bf705b14b564106426a2e57299638fb178750
See-Also: https://review.openstack.org/502306 (nova spec)
See-Also: https://review.openstack.org/508149 (neutron spec)

commit_message:
Improve cinder::nova support for auth_type password

Add ability to configure the [nova] settings required when the auth_type
is password. This allows cinder to access the nova API as a privileged
user.

Change-Id: Ia357ea41f8472d47e266d853f120a14b767e880d

(1 comment)

Great start, Zane.

I was wondering if we should not have a bit about dependencies. We have a list of base services (that we say is "safe" to depend on) but should we encourage dependencies between OpenStack components (think: reuse as much as we can, have anything that requires a workflow depend on Mistral) or on the contrary limit dependencies as much as we can (avoid creating crazy dependencies on lesser-used components, encourage standalone operation) ?

Our position on that evolved a bit over time, so I think it would be great to cover in this document.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-08-21 14:13:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-08-21 15:03:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-08-21 16:02:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-08-22 10:02:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-09-06 16:22:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-09-06 16:23:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2018-09-08 11:16:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Zane, thanks for asking for my thoughts on this.

I'm a little rushed right now (between flights for a work trip to Bangalore, and the next week I won't have time to do much open stuff, so please forgive me if I touch on things others have (I read the proposal on the plane from cheap clone...)

Also, I have not been tracking OpenStack super closely for a while now, so if I reference fixed things - sorry!

Let me first say I like what you write, and I think that getting consensus around that would be great.

It seems to me that much of it is what I would call a product vision: its not going to be of great help guiding the day to day coding / testing / work selection / or to a lesser degree architecture choices folk may make.

Riffing on that, you could kindof structure what you wrote like this:

 product vision
 
 - minimum requirements
   (basically nothing)
 
 - what deployers and or distributors bring to it themselves
   monitoring? observability? alerting? availability?
 
 - what it offers users
   - APIs that help you write:
     a) efficient, reliable (even at scale in noisy environments) software
        such as swift, or autoscaling groups
     b) operate such software
   - data centre management (more of an offering to deployers, perhaps?). And do we really offer that today? Perhaps we should?
   - consistency in use from micro scales through to global
     (e.g. you don't need a whole new Swift API just because your site is growing)
     (e.g. you can horizontally scale an app comprising stateless Nova VMs)


To my mind in a technical vision its important to give folk a framework to make choices between. Choices like 'is this tested enough?'. Or 'should we wrap that third party API, or merely provide service discovery and credential integration for it?'

Crucially though, is the heirarchy: when we can't have all the things, which things do we give up first? The product vision should be ultimate, and then supporting it which things are key and which things are desirable?

Giving guidance there means having some sort of shape that we want OpenStack to have technically (nb: not an implementation decree!) and finding ways to express it - which I think you are heading towards :).


Here are some things I think we could build a consensus around, either the thing itself, or the properties that drive our existing norms...:

should components be deep or wide? I don't mean in the big tent sense, but rather how much functionality folk should get from a given API. For instance: if you get a heap of functionality out of an API document with 20 fields, and its very reusable, thats great. If you have 10 2 field documents, and only get trivial functionality out of each sub API, thats a lot harder to track. (This is perhaps not expressed well, but you can imagine forming a view there). I'm sure you can think of some super-specific, little-return-on-knowning-them APIs w/in OpenStack :)


Given the choice of implementing functionality or orchestrating external implementations, which is preferrable? If its case by case, what are the broad characteristics to be considered? We wouldn't consider implementing a hypervisor in OpenStack to be a good idea - but lets capture what it is about *not doing that* that is good for OpenStack.


Should domain APIs be pluggable, or concrete to a specific implementation? (libvirt-only, or extensible across many ...)

How much coupling should be present within OpenStack? Loose? Tight? What forms of connaisence are considered ok?

How reliable should OpenStack components be out of the box? How many 9's should a devstack cloud deliver?

How much overhead should OpenStack consume just to run?

What latency is acceptable for operations w/in OpenStack? Both DB only things, and also time to react and actually provision or whatever?

Should APIs be actions, or should the system be built around a declared state + control loop model?

APIs should be consistent across scales. Operating on 1 thing could be different to 2, but 2 and 2000 should be the same.

How much code should be needed for new components? How much copy-paste?

How important is having things in the system be unique/avoid overlap? E.g. for node agents, should the a single unique thing, or is having 10 ok?

Anyhow hope that helps, happy to have a longer discussion, or a more interactive one, if you like."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-09-21 20:45:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-09-25 09:51:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(5 comments)

Great addition(s)! It's getting close. See minor improvements suggestions inline."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-09-25 16:10:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)

Zane, as a general comment, I'd like to see more precise usage of "user" (generally towards the bottom of the doc). It's not clear if that's an app dev/api client/paying customer sort of user or if it's the administrator. I know "who is the user" is a perennial question in OpenStack, but perhaps being more precise in this document, or offering a specific definition, would help avoid that ambiguity here.'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2018-10-26 19:30:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-26 20:34:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-10-26 20:49:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

Thanks again Zane.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-10-26 22:54:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)

I got stuck in the "Pillars of Cloud" section but hopefully left some useful comments there.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-27 01:51:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)

> It's not clear if that's an app dev/api client/paying customer sort of user or if it's the administrator.

I always try to use 'end-user' for the former and 'cloud operator' for the latter. (I'm aware that 'end-user' is too context-dependent, because the *end* user is probably the customer of some SaaS application running in the cloud, several levels of abstraction away... but unfortunately people calling operators 'users' has ruined the word 'user' for everyone.) If you see 'user' it means 'end-user', but I'll go through and try to make sure nothing ambiguous gets left in."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-10-29 15:14:59.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from tech-vision to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-31 16:52:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-11-01 04:28:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-11-01 10:55:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Where does this place the state of deployment projects?  Does this mean that they don't fit in OpenStack anymore?"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-11-01 15:03:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Where does this place the state of deployment projects? Does this mean that they don't fit in OpenStack anymore?

They're not within the scope *of the document*, which just talks about the cloud services. But the document does not affect the scope of the OpenStack project at all; we'll still have deployment tools and client libraries and all the other stuff from the project map as official OpenStack projects. Perhaps one day we'll even write a 'Vision for OpenStack Deployment', but this isn't it :)

This is mentioned explicitly on ll. 38-39, but if you can suggest a way to make it more clear then I'm all ears."}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-11-01 15:07:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-11-01 16:09:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-11-02 16:45:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

Still good'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2018-11-02 17:40:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Zane came to the manila meeting this last week and after some discussion the consensus was that the manila project aligns quite well with the Design Goals articulated in the Vision Statement -- particularly with Basic Physical Data Center Management and Hardware Virtualization (it actually virtualizes both hardware back ends and software defined storage, and Abstracts Specialized Operations on these.) Through the "share type" abstraction and its APIs manila can enable programs to work at an abstract level with back ends that allow for Infinite, Continuous Scaling.  And Manila's APIs and its client allow for integration into GUIs, including Horizon.  Manila plays well with others in and outside of OpenStack -- it has no dependency on hypervisors to serve up storage, can run with or without keystone, integrates with neutron via a plugin infrastructure -- by keeping itself loosely coupled with other OpenStack services.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-11-05 14:32:02.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from tech-vision to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-05 18:14:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

Let's make this go. It's good as is, and is designed as an evolving document.

The test comes when we try to use it to authorise some other change or activity. Let's see what happens."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2018-11-07 22:27:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

on behalf of the swift project team'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-11-07 22:39:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

commit_message:
Add a Vision statement for OpenStack clouds

Set out a vision for OpenStack clouds that clarifies, in long form, the
meaning of the mission statement at a technical level. Define what we
mean by 'cloud', describe how OpenStack must be different from other
cloud offerings, and list the design goals that we hope the OpenStack
system as a whole will achieve.

Change-Id: Ie988d87365cd2e190f2c6c13ee178f1590e4642d

commit_message:
Purge old packages on upgrade-charm

On charm upgrade the charm may switch to py3 packages. If so, ensure
the old py2 packages are purged. If the purge occurs then restart
services.

Change-Id: I984a227b3fe12a0086c926ae69c27d6e4d9741d3
Closes-Bug: 1803451

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23757, 'date': '2017-10-27 12:55:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-10-28 18:59:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

As I commented in the blueprint, I have very basic question. Even though we introduces the parallelism with futurist but someone says the experienced performance decreased after the change (I forgot the actual source though), so I think this kind of things should be done with performance data.

-- 
Could you show the fact that how making fetching resources in parallel contributes the speedup? Does futurist used in the proposed review use native threads rather than python greenthread? If so, this changes the way of optimization as it changes the balance of apache configurations like the number of processes or workers. At a first glance, I am not sure at all how this contributes the total performance.
--'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2018-09-06 07:47:13.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This review is > 4 months without comment, and failed Jenkins the last time it was checked. We are abandoning this for now. commit_message:
Make API calls in Volumes view parallel

In order to increase rendering speed, make
api.cinder.volume_list_paged, api.nova.server_list
and api.cinder.volume_snapshot_list parallel.
For admin panel also api.keystone.tenant_list is
parallelized.

Closes-bug: #1660025
Partial-implements: blueprint fetch-resources-in-parallel

Change-Id: Ic789ff98a59ba792d77103e7778883562e7977d2

commit_message:
Purge old packages on upgrade-charm

On charm upgrade the charm may switch to py3 packages. If so, ensure
the old py2 packages are purged. If the purge occurs then restart
services.

Change-Id: I3e67d35324888522f6c138ebd74a2ea7f1a4ce05
Closes-Bug: 1803451

commit_message:
Handle validation failure if not all switch fields received

The Ironic API has a validation on the LocalLinkConnectionType to
ensure all mandatory values are included. Handle failures which
could occur if the switch does not send all mandatory fields.

Change-Id: I8716a69586265a58520cc2c6bc0bbc00a7c159da
Story: 2004238
Task: 27761

commit_message:
multitenancy: Don't use fixed IPs in the test

Currently used fixed IPs didn't work on cloud with HA controllers as one
of IP addresses collided with an address assigned to DHCP port. This
patch removes fixed IPs and lets Neutron to assign IP to booted
instances. Later, those addresses are taken from server response and
reused.

Story: 2004330
Task: 27913

Change-Id: I3335ae43c17298f48cf869553e393df9ba7a070b

commit_message:
Add documentation for routed interfaces

Using the container_(extra)_networks hash a user can define a routed
interface for a network without an address. This change documents that
capability.

Change-Id: I93bdfde1aa5a9820d1853a779caf6670ee58d335
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit 7ba42bc3d70eecd227505155e5261677cac84762)

--- a/magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernetes/fragments/configure-kubernetes-master.sh
+++ b/magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernetes/fragments/configure-kubernetes-master.sh
@@ -1,4 +1,4 @@
-#!/bin/sh
+#!/bin/bash
 
 . /etc/sysconfig/heat-params
 
@@ -25,7 +25,7 @@ CONTAINER_REGISTRY=${CONTAINER_INFRA_PREFIX:-docker.io/openstackmagnum/}
 #############################################################################
 
 SYSTEM_IMAGES=(
-    "--name=kube-scheduler ${CONTAINER_REGISTRY}kubernetes-proxy:${KUBE_TAG}"
+    "--name=kube-scheduler ${CONTAINER_REGISTRY}kubernetes-scheduler:${KUBE_TAG}"
     "--name=kube-apiserver ${CONTAINER_REGISTRY}kubernetes-apiserver:${KUBE_TAG}"
     "--name=kube-controller-manager ${CONTAINER_REGISTRY}kubernetes-controller-manager:${KUBE_TAG}"
 )
@@ -94,7 +94,7 @@ echo "KUBE_PROXY_ARGS=\"${KUBE_PROXY_ARGS}\"" > /etc/kubernetes/proxy
 # configure general config: TODO: make configurable
 # ############################################################################
 
-cat > /etc/kubernetes/config < EOF
+cat > /etc/kubernetes/config << EOF
 ###
 # Kubernetes System Config
 #
@@ -180,6 +180,7 @@ if [ "${CERT_MANAGER_API}" == "True" ]; then
     KUBE_CONTROLLER_MANAGER_ARGS+=("--cluster-signing-key-file=${CERT_DIR}/ca.key")
 fi
 
+KUBE_CONTROLLER_MANAGER_ARGS=$(printf "%s " "${KUBE_CONTROLLER_MANAGER_ARGS[@]}")
 echo "KUBE_CONTROLLER_MANAGER_ARGS=\"${KUBE_CONTROLLER_MANAGER_ARGS}\"" > /etc/kubernetes/controller-manager
 
 #############################################################################
@@ -272,7 +273,7 @@ fi
 if [ "${NETWORK_DRIVER}" == "calico" ]; then
     KUBELET_ARGS+=("--network-plugin=cni --cni-conf-dir=/etc/cni/net.d --cni-bin-dir=/opt/cni/bin")
     systemctl disable docker
-    if cat /usr/lib/systemd/system/docker.service | grep 'native.cgroupdriver'; then
+    if grep -q 'native.cgroupdriver' /usr/lib/systemd/system/docker.service ; then
             cp /usr/lib/systemd/system/docker.service /etc/systemd/system/
             sed -i "s/\(native.cgroupdriver=\)\w\+/\1${CGROUP_DRIVER}/" \
                     /etc/systemd/system/docker.service'}, {'account_id': 28411, 'date': '2018-08-15 14:46:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

'}, {'created': '2018-08-15 14:55:26.000000000', 'message': 'cleanup config-k8s-masters.sh, added roles to nodes on startup

This cleans up a single file and prepares for future modifications
such as the kube-proxy and kubelet for masters.
1) This adds the master role to the nodes in the most efficient manner.
2) This overrides the config files for the static system files because
those should not have preset values and should be placed all at once
to be more visible to the user for readability and debugging.
3) This will remove the obsolete capability with KUBE<=1.8.0, not
recommended for backport.

Task: 22247

commit_message:
cleanup config-k8s-masters.sh, added roles to nodes on startup

This cleans up a single file and prepares for future modifications
such as the kube-proxy and kubelet for masters.
1) This adds the master role to the nodes in the most efficient manner.
2) This overrides the config files for the static system files because
those should not have preset values and should be placed all at once
to be more visible to the user for readability and debugging.
3) This will remove the obsolete capability with KUBE<=1.8.0, not
recommended for backport.

Task: 22247
Story: 2002618
Change-Id: I2086e83bc270b33227f799611b571e1fbadf08cc

commit_message:
Use dnf and python3 on platforms where these are default

Roles do not need to make any assumptions about having some facts
already gathered, thus at start they should assure they gather any
missiong facts that are used inside the role.

Change-Id: I49fd1a0c070d96aecb880164acde490c9e7c95ef
Story: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/153
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/615489/

there seems to be some out of tree code which doesn't specify the service module arg.
can you consider to add some clarifications about what should be specified as YOUR_SERVICE_MODULE in our doc?
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/c16d15fff2953c7427dc2671dc479d044d5b90c3/doc/source/contributor/contribute.rst#service-providers"}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2018-04-17 12:17:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26970, 'date': '2018-04-17 13:53:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> (1 comment)

Good point. This change do break the configuration and that's what I was afraid of. 
I want to make minimal change, and at a glance there is no service provider having different module path from service_plugin module. And it was not true. T_T Thanks for letting me know.

Logically module path is not related to service type and I found there was old commit to delete the dependency. (d24633a4688b951f2b4d29b3248019588b3e198a). 

The other solution that I tried is to pass additional 'service type' arg to ProviderConfiguration class, and use the service type to match service provider.
It seems to be logically right, but I hesitated to do because it makes more change and also break Service plugin out of tree. (If there is)

IMHO, I should go back to what I tried since now this patch is unsuitable. Please let me know if there is better solution you think. commit_message:
Select service_provider on the basis of service_module

In case of service_provider, selection according to service type is
necessary. Currently there was no filtering logic, so if there are two
or more service plugins using service_provider, there is a duplicate
service_provider.

New argument 'svc_type' is added to ProviderConfiguration so that only
the service_provider matching the service type is shown.

From caller side of ProviderConfiguration, one should specify
'svc_type' since ProviderConfiguration class have new 'svc_type'
argument to find service provider. Although netron code base using
ProviderConfiguration changed, existed code out of newtron tree should
be also modified following the change becuase if not, there would be
duplicated entries problem currently appeared. But there is no
difference without 'svc_type' argument because matching is effective
only when the argument is specified.

A new test case added in test_get_service_providers() in
neutron/tests/unit/extensions/test_servicetype.py which does not
have any filter options. Without this patch, this test case would be
failed having duplicated results.

Change-Id: I6ad9897dd174b45c7f2315699d25d38d4c060abc
Closes-Bug: #1763627

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-31 16:48:09.000000000', 'message': 'Handle retry logic for timeouts with multiple LDAP servers

It is currently possible to specify multiple LDAP server URIs
for failover purposes when using LDAP connection pooling, as this
functionality is provided in the underlying python-ldap module.
Unfortunately, failover does not work properly if LDAP timeout
issue are encountered due to the way python-LDAP works.  If multiple
URLs are provided, the first URL that results in a successful TCP
connection is considered to be a successful LDAP connection.  If the
initial bind operation fails due to a timeout waiting for an LDAP
response from the server, it will never failover to additional
URIs.  It is easy to demonstrate this behavior by forcing an LDAP
server to hang (attach with gdb to halt the process), then using
that server as the first URI when creating a connection pool.

This patch adds proper failover logic to ldappool.  If multiple URIs
are provided, we split them and attempt to connect to them one-by-one
until we have either had a successful LDAP bind operation, or we have
exhausted the list of URIs.  The connection retry logic is processed
per-URI as well, meaning we will attempt to reconnect to the first
URI up to the requested retry limit, then we will failover to the
next URI and reset the retry count.

The ldap.TIMEOUT exception was not raised to the caller like some
of the other common LDAP exceptions we might encounter.  We should
raise the TIMEOUT exception instead of the more generic BackendError
exception to provide more detail to the calling code.

Change-Id: Iabc13363d2425e70a53163249e5389d336274533
'}, {'created': '2018-10-31 19:40:29.000000000', 'message': 'Handle retry logic for timeouts with multiple LDAP servers

response from the server, it will never failover to additional

server to hang (attach with gdb to halt the process), then using
that server as the first URI when creating a connection pool.

This patch adds proper failover logic to ldappool.  If multiple URIs
are provided, we split them and attempt to connect to them one-by-one
until we have either had a successful LDAP bind operation, or we have
exhausted the list of URIs.  The connection retry logic is processed
per-URI as well, meaning we will attempt to reconnect to the first
URI up to the requested retry limit, then we will failover to the
next URI and reset the retry count.

The ldap.TIMEOUT exception was not raised to the caller like some
of the other common LDAP exceptions we might encounter.  We should
raise the TIMEOUT exception instead of the more generic BackendError
exception to provide more detail to the calling code.

Change-Id: Iabc13363d2425e70a53163249e5389d336274533
'}]
commit_message:
Handle retry logic for timeouts with multiple LDAP servers

It is currently possible to specify multiple LDAP server URIs
for failover purposes when using LDAP connection pooling, as this
functionality is provided in the underlying python-ldap module.
Unfortunately, failover does not work properly if LDAP timeout
issue are encountered due to the way python-LDAP works.  If multiple
URLs are provided, the first URL that results in a successful TCP
connection is considered to be a successful LDAP connection.  If the
initial bind operation fails due to a timeout waiting for an LDAP
response from the server, it will never failover to additional
URIs.  It is easy to demonstrate this behavior by forcing an LDAP
server to hang (attach with gdb to halt the process), then using
that server as the first URI when creating a connection pool.

This patch adds proper failover logic to ldappool.  If multiple URIs
are provided, we split them and attempt to connect to them one-by-one
until we have either had a successful LDAP bind operation, or we have
exhausted the list of URIs.  The connection retry logic is processed
per-URI as well, meaning we will attempt to reconnect to the first
URI up to the requested retry limit, then we will failover to the
next URI and reset the retry count.

The ldap.TIMEOUT exception was not raised to the caller like some
of the other common LDAP exceptions we might encounter.  We should
raise the TIMEOUT exception instead of the more generic BackendError
exception to provide more detail to the calling code.

Change-Id: Iabc13363d2425e70a53163249e5389d336274533

commit_message:
Purge old packages on upgrade-charm

On charm upgrade the charm may switch to py3 packages. If so, ensure
the old py2 packages are purged. If the purge occurs then restore
the glance-api-paste.ini from packages and restart services.

Closes-Bug: 1803451
Change-Id: Ib258873fb2be95821e8f8c22fd1f3d19666b3181

[{'created': '2018-11-08 20:20:08.000000000', 'message': 'Cache swift responses in process_environments_and_files

process_environments_and_files retrieves all the environment files from
swift, but those can be referenced from multiple places, and thus be
retrieved multiple time. Cache them direclty here for now, until we fix
the heatclient utility function.

Change-Id: Ibc34bf0afcbf73e3a9c130dbb06c80141048494b
'}]
commit_message:
Cache swift responses in process_environments_and_files

process_environments_and_files retrieves all the environment files from
swift, but those can be referenced from multiple places, and thus be
retrieved multiple time. Cache them direclty here for now, until we fix
the heatclient utility function.

Change-Id: Ibc34bf0afcbf73e3a9c130dbb06c80141048494b

[{'created': '2018-11-05 15:40:47.000000000', 'message': 'Certificate changes should restart services

Certificate changes or path changes in octavia::certificate
should notify the octavia::service::begin anchor so that services
are refreshed otherwise for example octavia-worker will not use a
new certificate.

Change-Id: Ie03cfedccc6a675976688a944b1ee91a0a9f55f1
'}]
commit_message:
Certificate changes should restart services

Certificate changes or path changes in octavia::certificate
should notify the octavia::service::begin anchor so that services
are refreshed otherwise for example octavia-worker will not use a
new certificate.

Change-Id: Ie03cfedccc6a675976688a944b1ee91a0a9f55f1

commit_message:
Add ftp(s) support for freezer

Currently, freezer can only support local, ssh(support ssh_key_path),
swift, s3 as backup data storage, so we should increase support for
ftp, ftps(support password).

Story: #2004332
Task: #27917

Change-Id: I83f108b998673921d001bef71b247c5906ab2c83

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/596432 added vexxhost
provider, since then jobs running under "rdo-cloud"
provider are broken. This patch adds regex match with
"rdo-cloud"* to handle both rdo-cloud and rdo-cloud-tripleo.

Closes-Bug: #1803133
Change-Id: I9a7ddef4e4f57dc599b9030a0afbe116b1075b68
'}]
commit_message:
Also support rdo-cloud provider

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/596432 added vexxhost
provider, since then jobs running under "rdo-cloud"
provider are broken. This patch adds regex match with
"rdo-cloud"* to handle both rdo-cloud and rdo-cloud-tripleo.

Closes-Bug: #1803133
Change-Id: I9a7ddef4e4f57dc599b9030a0afbe116b1075b68

"}, {'created': '2018-11-06 01:58:42.000000000', 'message': "Don't quote {posargs} in tox.ini

commit_message:
Don't quote {posargs} in tox.ini

Quotes around {posargs} cause the entire string to be combined into one
arg that gets passed to stestr. This prevents passing multiple args
(e.g. '--concurrency=16 some-regex')

Change-Id: I0b09424dd3cef244e8cec1ef87b5992ccb9d5b07
Closes-Bug:#1801823

commit_message:
Support for libvirt volume multipath

Adds support for libvirt volume_use_multipath the ability to
use multipath connection of the iSCSI or FC volume.
Volumes can be connected in the LibVirt as multipath devices.
Adds new parameter "nova::compute::libvirt::volume_use_multipath"

Change-Id: I029ee781caf17c83b6a7d3044f1d18450150cefb
(cherry picked from commit 50797656a677cc18f21bad4c06482d1385dd3e43)

commit_message:
Pass global enviroment variables

The install-deps.sh script is sometimes used in a server sitting
behind a corporated network, for those scenarios is necessary to
pass proxy global environment variables. This change enables that
for fedora/centos OSes.

Change-Id: Ic327168eec892970cd2d7dd4b24d92fa0deee184

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-15 10:01:00.000000000', 'message': 'Deal with obsolete packages during charm upgrade

For Rocky, we switch the payload execution environent from py2->py3
post initial charm release; ensure that any existing py2 based
deployments are automatically switched over to py3 during any
charm upgrade.

This is implemented in the default upgrade-charm handler code; if
packages are removed as part of the upgrade, all services associated
with the charm will be restarted.

Change-Id: Ib5f11d21dd26cb2918f5d5044ed56d688bba3b5d
Closes-Bug: 1803451
'}, {'created': '2018-11-15 10:54:28.000000000', 'message': 'Deal with obsolete packages during charm upgrade

For Rocky, we switch the payload execution environent from py2->py3
post initial charm release; ensure that any existing py2 based
deployments are automatically switched over to py3 during any
charm upgrade.

This is implemented in the default upgrade-charm handler code; if
packages are removed as part of the upgrade, all services associated
with the charm will be restarted.

Change-Id: Ib5f11d21dd26cb2918f5d5044ed56d688bba3b5d
Closes-Bug: 1803451
'}]
commit_message:
Deal with obsolete packages during charm upgrade

For Rocky, we switch the payload execution environent from py2->py3
post initial charm release; ensure that any existing py2 based
deployments are automatically switched over to py3 during any
charm upgrade.

This is implemented in the default upgrade-charm handler code; if
packages are removed as part of the upgrade, all services associated
with the charm will be restarted.

Change-Id: Ib5f11d21dd26cb2918f5d5044ed56d688bba3b5d
Closes-Bug: 1803451

subject: Do not purge the Ironic Inspector dhcp-hostsdir
messages:
[{'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2018-11-09 11:34:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2018-11-10 10:01:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 21909, 'date': '2018-11-14 19:44:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2018-11-15 08:33:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

clean cherrypick'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-09 11:34:16.000000000', 'message': 'Do not purge the Ironic Inspector dhcp-hostsdir

Since the ironic-inspector service and the dnsmasq
service for ironic-inspector is running in different
containters, having the ironic-inspector service
start/stop the dnsmasq service is non-trivial.

Using `--pid="host"` and making the containers
priviligeied seems less than ideal.

This changes the ironic-inspector configuration so
that it will no longer purge the dhcp-hosts dir on
intialization. Purging the directory without also
restarting (or HUP) the dnsmasq service can cause
the configuration in the DHCP service to deviate
from what ironic-inspector intend it to be.

Related-Bug: #1780421
Depends-On: Icc532115891c567dde20a28110bf08f54187c49f
Change-Id: Id26b578b57c46f9993459f83b5f90393d7798a82
(cherry picked from commit 48e7aba0bfb116b9370cc337eb966cd27393a7e5)
'}]
commit_message:
Do not purge the Ironic Inspector dhcp-hostsdir

Since the ironic-inspector service and the dnsmasq
service for ironic-inspector is running in different
containters, having the ironic-inspector service
start/stop the dnsmasq service is non-trivial.

Using `--pid="host"` and making the containers
priviligeied seems less than ideal.

This changes the ironic-inspector configuration so
that it will no longer purge the dhcp-hosts dir on
intialization. Purging the directory without also
restarting (or HUP) the dnsmasq service can cause
the configuration in the DHCP service to deviate
from what ironic-inspector intend it to be.

Related-Bug: #1780421
Depends-On: Icc532115891c567dde20a28110bf08f54187c49f
Change-Id: Id26b578b57c46f9993459f83b5f90393d7798a82
(cherry picked from commit 48e7aba0bfb116b9370cc337eb966cd27393a7e5)

[{'created': '2018-10-31 14:45:05.000000000', 'message': 'Increase size of EFI system partition

8 MiB is not enough when using the grub2 element with centos7 images,
which installs binaries from the shim-x64 and grub2-efi-x64 packages
under /boot/efi. 12 MiB ought to be enough for anybody.

Change-Id: I8594d1fe05242f246a5809740a115ab2f84ac5a3
'}]
commit_message:
Increase size of EFI system partition

8 MiB is not enough when using the grub2 element with centos7 images,
which installs binaries from the shim-x64 and grub2-efi-x64 packages
under /boot/efi. 12 MiB ought to be enough for anybody.

Change-Id: I8594d1fe05242f246a5809740a115ab2f84ac5a3

Ok now i know what you're doing and why. This is a breaking change because of something called database versioning[1] You need to create a new file to tell the database how you want it to upgrade. Take a look at changes that do this already[2] here is one in particular[3]. You can find migrate_repo.schema here[4] this will provide you with the framework to implement the upgrade function. Looks like you want to update the column and I don't see any tools for that so try dropping the table and creating it again and see if that works.

[1] http://enterprisecraftsmanship.com/2015/08/10/database-versioning-best-practices/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:merged+project:openstack/trove+file:versions
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/417487/10/trove/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/042_add_cluster_configuration_id.py
[4] https://github.com/openstack/trove/blob/master/trove/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/schema.py"}, {'account_id': 20378, 'date': '2017-03-17 21:23:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

 > Looks like you want to update the column and I don't see any tools

 > that works.

 > [1] http://enterprisecraftsmanship.com/2015/08/10/database-versioning-best-practices/
 > [2] https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:merged+project:openstack/trove+file:versions
 > [3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/417487/10/trove/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/042_add_cluster_configuration_id.py
 > [4] https://github.com/openstack/trove/blob/master/trove/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/schema.py

The Table definition comes from sqlalchemy.schema so see if there is a update_column, or something simpler than dropping and creating a table."}, {'account_id': 21387, 'date': '2017-03-18 01:54:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

As said in Commit Message and the issue in the bug, the show output is about the value which was filled with SQL_mode for some specific syntax.
SQL_mode offers some kind of portability and flexibility.

"The MySQL server can operate in different SQL modes, and can apply these modes differently for different clients, depending on the value of the sql_mode system variable. DBAs can set the global SQL mode to match site server operating requirements, and each application can set its session SQL mode to its own requirements.

Database | Sql_mode
DB2|	PIPES_AS_CONCAT、ANSI_QUOTES、IGNORE_SPACE、NO_KEY_OPTIONS、NO_TABLE_OPTIONS、NO_FIELD_OPTIONS
MAXDB	PIPES_AS_CONCAT、ANSI_QUOTES、IGNORE_SPACE、NO_KEY_OPTIONS、NO_TABLE_OPTIONS、NO_FIELD_OPTIONS、 NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER
MSSQL|  	PIPES_AS_CONCAT、ANSI_QUOTES、IGNORE_SPACE、NO_KEY_OPTIONS、NO_TABLE_OPTIONS、 NO_FIELD_OPTIONS
ORACLE|         PIPES_AS_CONCAT、ANSI_QUOTES、IGNORE_SPACE、NO_KEY_OPTIONS、NO_TABLE_OPTIONS、NO_FIELD_OPTIONS、NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER
POSTGRESQL|	PIPES_AS_CONCAT、ANSI_QUOTES、IGNORE_SPACE、NO_KEY_OPTIONS、NO_TABLE_OPTIONS、NO_FIELD_OPTIONS

Modes affect the SQL syntax MySQL supports and the data validation checks it performs. This makes it easier to use MySQL in different environments and to use MySQL together with other database servers."


mysql> create table t5 (c1 char(3));
mysql> insert into t5 values('abcd');
mysql> select * from t5;
+------+
| c1 |
+------+
| abc |
+------+
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

mysql> set session sql_mode='STRICT_TRANS_TABLES'

mysql> insert into t5 values('abcd');
ERROR 1406 (22001): Data too long for column 'c1' at row 1


If the column value really has some other usage, we actually consider to change the value column type from (varchar|string) to (text), then there is no limit for length.
For the key filled in "SQL_mode" nowadays, it just affects the SQL_mode for portability. So I just think change to String(512) is enough. (For MySQL5.7, the whole SQL_mode length is 407 strings.)

Finally, what's your opinion, amrith?
Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 25105, 'date': '2017-03-25 00:03:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Published edit on patch set 16'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-03-25 02:37:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Verified+1

'}, {'created': '2017-03-17 01:59:15.000000000', 'message': 'fix bug#1672263 which table configurations.value

It's a fix about cli command when runs with: trove configuration-create.


when running: 
>trove configuration-create limit_128_test ' 
{ "sql_mode": "\"ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY,STRICT_TRANS_TABLES,NO_ZERO_IN_DATE,
NO_ZERO_DATE,ERROR_FOR_DIVISION_BY_ZERO,NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER,
NO_ENGINE_SUBSTITUTION\"" } ' --datastore pxc --datastore_version pxc56

output:
>trove configuration-show xxxxx
the configuration value gets truncated when over 128 char.


As is known to all, MySQL server can operate in different SQL modes, 
and can apply these modes differently for different clients, 
depending on the value of the sql_mode system variable. 
DBAs can set the global SQL mode to match site server operating 
requirements, and each application can set its session SQL mode 
to its own requirements.
Modes affect the SQL syntax MySQL supports and the data validation 
checks it performs. This makes it easier to use MySQL in different 
environments and to use MySQL together with other database servers.


As below, I explain about the importance of SQL_mode in MySQL server.


>>> sql_mode="ALLOW_INVALID_DATES,ANSI_QUOTES,
ERROR_FOR_DIVISION_BY_ZERO,HIGH_NOT_PRECEDENCE,
IGNORE_SPACE,NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER,NO_AUTO_VALUE_ON_ZERO,
NO_BACKSLASH_ESCAPES,NO_DIR_IN_CREATE,NO_ENGINE_SUBSTITUTION,
NO_FIELD_OPTIONS,NO_KEY_OPTIONS,NO_TABLE_OPTIONS,
NO_UNSIGNED_SUBTRACTION,NO_ZERO_DATE,NO_ZERO_IN_DATE,
ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY,PAD_CHAR_TO_FULL_LENGTH,PIPES_AS_CONCAT,
REAL_AS_FLOAT,STRICT_ALL_TABLES,STRICT_TRANS_TABLES"
>>> len(sql_mode)
407


So I changed the Table configurations and datastore_version_metadata 
which changed the column value from String(128) to String(512).


Change-Id: Ifcc77788d269602029b0f4261090d3955b65fdab

the configuration value gets truncated when over 128 char.

As is known to all, MySQL server can operate in different SQL modes,
and can apply these modes differently for different clients,
depending on the value of the sql_mode system variable.
DBAs can set the global SQL mode to match site server operating
requirements, and each application can set its session SQL mode
to its own requirements.
Modes affect the SQL syntax MySQL supports and the data validation
checks it performs. This makes it easier to use MySQL in different
environments and to use MySQL together with other database servers.

As below, I explain about the importance of SQL_mode in MySQL server.

>>> sql_mode="ALLOW_INVALID_DATES,ANSI_QUOTES,
ERROR_FOR_DIVISION_BY_ZERO,HIGH_NOT_PRECEDENCE,
IGNORE_SPACE,NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER,NO_AUTO_VALUE_ON_ZERO,
NO_BACKSLASH_ESCAPES,NO_DIR_IN_CREATE,NO_ENGINE_SUBSTITUTION,
NO_FIELD_OPTIONS,NO_KEY_OPTIONS,NO_TABLE_OPTIONS,
NO_UNSIGNED_SUBTRACTION,NO_ZERO_DATE,NO_ZERO_IN_DATE,
ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY,PAD_CHAR_TO_FULL_LENGTH,PIPES_AS_CONCAT,
REAL_AS_FLOAT,STRICT_ALL_TABLES,STRICT_TRANS_TABLES"
>>> len(sql_mode)
407

So I changed the Table configurations and datastore_version_metadata
which changed the column value from String(128) to String(512).

{ "sql_mode": "\"ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY,STRICT_TRANS_TABLES,NO_ZERO_IN_DATE,
NO_ZERO_DATE,ERROR_FOR_DIVISION_BY_ZERO,NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER,
NO_ENGINE_SUBSTITUTION\"" } ' --datastore pxc --datastore_version pxc56

output:
>trove configuration-show xxxxx
the configuration value gets truncated when over 128 char.

As is known to all, MySQL server can operate in different SQL modes,
and can apply these modes differently for different clients,
depending on the value of the sql_mode system variable.
DBAs can set the global SQL mode to match site server operating
requirements, and each application can set its session SQL mode
to its own requirements.
Modes affect the SQL syntax MySQL supports and the data validation
checks it performs. This makes it easier to use MySQL in different
environments and to use MySQL together with other database servers.

As below, I explain about the importance of SQL_mode in MySQL server.

>>> sql_mode="ALLOW_INVALID_DATES,ANSI_QUOTES,
ERROR_FOR_DIVISION_BY_ZERO,HIGH_NOT_PRECEDENCE,
IGNORE_SPACE,NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER,NO_AUTO_VALUE_ON_ZERO,
NO_BACKSLASH_ESCAPES,NO_DIR_IN_CREATE,NO_ENGINE_SUBSTITUTION,
NO_FIELD_OPTIONS,NO_KEY_OPTIONS,NO_TABLE_OPTIONS,
NO_UNSIGNED_SUBTRACTION,NO_ZERO_DATE,NO_ZERO_IN_DATE,
ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY,PAD_CHAR_TO_FULL_LENGTH,PIPES_AS_CONCAT,
REAL_AS_FLOAT,STRICT_ALL_TABLES,STRICT_TRANS_TABLES"
>>> len(sql_mode)
407

So I changed the Table configurations and datastore_version_metadata
which changed the column value from String(128) to String(512).

Change-Id: Ifcc77788d269602029b0f4261090d3955b65fdab
'}]
commit_message:
Trove configuration-create limit 128 varchar affects mysql SQL_MODE func

Fix bug#1672263 which table configurations.value affects cmd output show

update the columns from migrate_repo

when running:
>trove configuration-create limit_128_test '
{ "sql_mode": "\"ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY,STRICT_TRANS_TABLES,NO_ZERO_IN_DATE,
NO_ZERO_DATE,ERROR_FOR_DIVISION_BY_ZERO,NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER,
NO_ENGINE_SUBSTITUTION\"" } ' --datastore pxc --datastore_version pxc56

output:
>trove configuration-show xxxxx
the configuration value gets truncated when over 128 char.

As is known to all, MySQL server can operate in different SQL modes,
and can apply these modes differently for different clients,
depending on the value of the sql_mode system variable.
DBAs can set the global SQL mode to match site server operating
requirements, and each application can set its session SQL mode
to its own requirements.
Modes affect the SQL syntax MySQL supports and the data validation
checks it performs. This makes it easier to use MySQL in different
environments and to use MySQL together with other database servers.

As below, I explain about the importance of SQL_mode in MySQL server.

>>> sql_mode="ALLOW_INVALID_DATES,ANSI_QUOTES,
ERROR_FOR_DIVISION_BY_ZERO,HIGH_NOT_PRECEDENCE,
IGNORE_SPACE,NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER,NO_AUTO_VALUE_ON_ZERO,
NO_BACKSLASH_ESCAPES,NO_DIR_IN_CREATE,NO_ENGINE_SUBSTITUTION,
NO_FIELD_OPTIONS,NO_KEY_OPTIONS,NO_TABLE_OPTIONS,
NO_UNSIGNED_SUBTRACTION,NO_ZERO_DATE,NO_ZERO_IN_DATE,
ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY,PAD_CHAR_TO_FULL_LENGTH,PIPES_AS_CONCAT,
REAL_AS_FLOAT,STRICT_ALL_TABLES,STRICT_TRANS_TABLES"
>>> len(sql_mode)
407

So I changed the Table configurations and datastore_version_metadata
which changed the column value from String(128) to String(512).

Change-Id: Ifcc77788d269602029b0f4261090d3955b65fdab

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

Link to public document instead of private

and aprovment to view this document. This patch replaces
it by copy of this document.

Signed-off-by: Alexey Perevalov <a.perevalov@samsung.com>

[{'account_id': 27898, 'date': '2018-11-07 13:44:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27898, 'date': '2018-11-07 13:45:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2018-11-07 13:54:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27898, 'date': '2018-11-07 14:53:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2018-11-07 15:37:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-11-07 18:01:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I don't think we want to do that right now.  I think our expectation will be that /usr/bin/python points to python3 but that's still TBD. I've tested this with python3 so i know the code is fine but we do need to figure out a better solution"}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2018-11-07 18:39:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Alex, your assumption about the symlink is dangereus

Please read https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0394/

If you also check the PSF mailing list and the PRs you will find that my attempt to update this PEP failed, Guido as keeping his possition.

Shortly: we do not expect to have a python command. This may be created by us but by default this command is likely to be missing.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-11-07 18:41:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

For our deployment on python3 versions we might be able to work around this due to historical reasons. commit_message:
Use correct python version for puppet-docker.py

Now that we are running this at fedora28 with python3 we need to use
python3 to run python scripts at playbooks

Depends-On: I2c471724374da44eeddc4680b268bc362572ee27
Closes-Bug: #1802531
Change-Id: I42b18b228bfe361d19b580a853328c1a6c896257
